Call it an intellectual challenge, sit back and wait for the critics to call it a masterpiece.To be fair there are some talented actors, camera and sound people involved in this. There are some nice clothes and in a couple of short scenes a nice lack of them. But you can see all those in a cheap weekly celebrity magazine and it won't take 2 hours and 25 minutes of your life to do it.I have heard that Kubrick's 2001 is considered by some to be a masterpiece because no one understands the ending. I never understood it anyway, but I did like the film. It had some fabulous things going on that were understandable right up to the last 20 minutes or so. Even at the end it was interesting to look at even if completely incomprehensible. Mulholland Dr. is just not in that category.Some arty intellectuals will say that I just didn't get it. That I am lacking in some way and that while the movie might be hard to figure out it is like a hard to figure out mathematical concept. Mathematics might be hard to understand but the fact is it can be understood. And all those who understand it will agree on what it means. In this case we have "no right answers". I have no objection to being left wondering if such and such a movie idea could really happen or, what if I were caught up in Groundhog Day or, did he/she really do it? But these are questions to do with aspects of a film not the entire "piece of work". Did I just not get it? I don't think so. I just noticed within minutes of the opening credits that the emperor had no clothes.

Review title: this just might be the worst ever
Review_body: Sure, i enjoy a movie that makes me think. I actually think those are the best movies out there. I however do not enjoy a movie that makes no sense no matter how much i think about it. I also don't think that a movie should have websites designed to offer their help in figuring out what happened. This movie just plain sucks. It is definitely not worth watching, unless you skip to the good part. And of course by the good part i mean the nudity. That is this movie's only redeeming quality. in short, this movie is completely worthless, don't even waste your time. And if you have seen this movie, and do truly enjoy it, there is something wrong with you. You are just searching for a reason to justify wasting 2 hours of your life, and are probably the same people who enjoyed sitting through Alexander. You think worthless movies aren't worthless because you want to consider yourself a movie fan. Just admit it, it sucks.

Maybe this does not qualify for a review, but at least these are my thoughts regarding this movie. This is one of those movies that was made deliberately to make no sense. Movie critics and all sorts of snobs see such a film and they think there must be something more to it. And then they search for something in it until they come up with something crazy to justify this movie's "greatness" even though that might just be their interpretation. Does ambiguity make a film great? Absolutely not. Is this movie something significantly more than a mess of scenes that are made to connect nonsensically? No, it isn't. Sure, the dream theory is nice but it definitely wasn't in the writer's head. It's not horrible, but nothing great either.

Review title: On of many David Lynch's masterpieces, and my favorite one.
Review_body: Diane (Naomi Watts) is a naive young woman who moves to Hollywood with dreams of becoming a movie star. She falls in love with a veteran actor, Camilla (Laura Harring), who brings her to glamorous industry parties and gets her bits and pieces of work. But Diane's just a casual fling, as she learns when she sees Camilla first get engaged to a man (Justin Theroux) and then move onto newer, younger mistresses. She has no intention of living with Diane or truly advancing her career -- so Diane hires a man (Mark Pellegrino) to kill her, and then kills herself.Most of the runtime isn't in reality, but in Diane's fantasy before dying. At the very beginning, the camera lowers onto a pillow; everything from there until the end is in her dream. But it's not an "It was all a dream!" twist or something lame like that -- it's pretty explicit about being a dream, and the dream is a way to depict Diane's fantasy life falling apart as reality intrudes, and to have everything you see show emotion and fantasies rather than boring reality.The dream begins with the hit on Camilla being carried out -- the guy up front pulls a gun. Then, miracle of miracles, a car crash saves her life, and kills her memory and personality. The amnesiac Camilla is a blank slate who is now reliant on Diane's care and has no connection to anyone but her. That's what Diane really wants, Camilla all to herself and all her rottenness gone, to not have to kill her.There are two diner scenes. In reality, this is where Diane hired the hit-man. A man stares at her, she imagines he knows what he sees. So in Diane's dream, which tries to suppress all of this information, the man is talking to his therapist, talking about something evil exists at that diner, which he can't bear to look at in his dreams, and how a man was looking at him, making him feel guilty. Diane is bitter and twisted at this point, and jealous of the younger, still-upbeat, still-naive waitress Betty -- in her dream, she takes the name Betty.If you watch the movie from this perspective, everything feels right; it retains the surreal mood of a dream, but the plot turns all fit into place. The dream is divided between these upbeat comedy sequences depicting Diane's fantasy -- Justin Theroux, who stole her SO, has his SO cheat on him (with Billy Ray Cyrus, for added humiliation) in a comical series of disasters, the hit men are inept, her auditions go amazingly -- and these very bleak, tense scenes where reality intrudes. The phone calls about missing girls, phone calls in her own voice, hearing that the movie will never get made because 'this is all bullshit.' The dream all comes breaking down when Diane discovers a corpse and finally remembers what the blue key is for (it's the sign the hit-man gives to indicate the completion of the job). The last thing you see in the dream is this extremely theatrical and beautifully-done concert performance being revealed as a tape playing over speakers, because none of this amazing stuff is real.Then the whole spirit of the movie is compressed into one minute for the scene where Diane masturbates thinking about Camilla while crying her eyes out.

This movie is too good for words. Captivating through its great camera work, intriguing in an almost demanding matter, brilliant performances by the whole cast, music that is enchantingly fitting and as usually things that don't make much sense but are thought-provoking and moving on a gut level. This is my favorite David Lynch film, and the film that first got me into his work which I encourage everyone to watch. For this film especially you might want to devote 3 or 4 viewings if you are eager to shed light to its mysterious and confusing plot-but trust me, it's worth it. All in all, one of the most powerful cinematic experiences you'll have for a long time.

If you know a thing or two about David Lynch, you know what to expect from him. In this case, Lynch had created a beautiful and weird love story, full of plot twists. The non-linear structure he uses it's perfect for this film and lets you thinking over and over about the sense of time and ordering in your mind several scenes and dialogs. I was very impressed by this film. I can compare its effect on me, solely with the hard and long-lasting emotions of books like Faulkner's The Soung and the fury or Borges' Fictions. It's the kind of film you love, or hate, but anyway, you ought to see it. I almost forget it. Naomy Campbell's work is astounding, by far her best ever. Laura Harrings also, proved herself as a great actress.

Could this movie have been better? No it couldn't. The acting is fantastic. She should have gotten an oscar for it. Story fantastic. Detail fantastic. The twist...... just fantastic. Best movie ever imo.

Review title: Must review this worst ever even after 1,928 other reviews
Review_body: It's telling that nearly 2000 people have felt the urge to appraise or tell their sincere opinion of this film.It's intriguing to read people second-guessing why would anyone rate this movie with anything above 2 (2 could be awarded for pity just in case the director somehow were able to do even worse). Besides, the actresses were pretty good.But I have a theory to add on top of those emperor's new clothes theme comments: people rate this high so as to make other people suffer as well. It doesn't help them, but at least those not having wasted their life for watching this movie would not have done that much better.From now on, I'll look into reviews of others before watching movies. Thanks for the lession, Mr. Lynch!

Don't believe the hype! Or do believe?This kind of films drives everyone crazy, and is for those with good will who believe in the good a topic for discussions for some days at least, for others it's a pure waste of time.I am writing this comment to get rid of the aftermath, I have watched this film half an hour ago, and my intention is to get an ANSWER! That is what probably everyone wants after watching this movie. Besides no one mentioned the term "mindfuck" what amazed me.It is absolutely to be categorized in the mindfuck genre, for those who are not familiar with this term have a look at wikipedia, or read the Illuminatus trilogy. In these books the meaning of mindfuck is just overloading the brain with that much nonsense with literally "no sense", so that the brain after endless loops trying to solve the riddle just "resets", and all brain washings you had had in your life are just erased and you are able to see the world as it really is. Just as far as I remember it.There is a hype about such kind of movies, they tend to get cult, although no one is able to describe the meaning, there are just some guessings. I am not that person who follows the hype, although I am quite impressed. And I do like solving riddles.OK, let us start systematically - what possibilities are there?A) It has got a meaning, but is just very (very very) hard to find.B)It is mindfuck. C) It is "art", i.e. compare it with a painting, there are always several interpretations, they just have an (subtle) effect. In other words: It works on the subconsciousness. Or - in other other words - it is dream-like.C: I cannot imagine this solution, therefor it is too much complicated and "mindfucking". And in my opinion, movies with a story line cannot just be art and just have effect. A story line implies something that can be understood by the mind.B: From the first impression: that's it. It has got no meaning. But why then this love for details, this sense for art and this truly complicated plot. What is the intention of Lynch? Is it just to confuse in a very artful way? Then it would be just manipulation of the viewer, to create a superhuman aura, why is someone creating and telling a riddle what cannot be solved? If this would be true I would be really enraged.A: Would be nice, but all the attempts of explanation I have read so far seem to be very far-fetched.Everyone thinks that just because no one is able to understand the plot Lynch has to be a genius, somehow superhuman. And the movie has to be great. Is it this way? I do not think so. I think staying on the ground is the best thing to do.But nevertheless I will try to solve this riddle, trying to get on the bottom of the plot. Perhaps Lynch has just a very complicated way of expressing things :).PS: As far as the vote is concerned: No extremes for this movie.

Worst movie I've ever seen, the only chance that I will ever watch it again is if I am being tortured and I am forced to watch it but there is a big chance that I will have spilled my guts before the title screen. I would much rather watch BloodRayne again that watch Mulholland Dr.This movie is not meant for entertainment and does not have a piece of string for you to follow because Lynch used a chainsaw and cut it to smaller pieces and then threw everything in a blender. It's a total mindfuck and for lack of a better word "sucks".So do yourselves a favor and watch porn instead if you want to see some random lesbo-scene.

This has to be the one of the worst movies i have ever seen, i'd rather torture myself by watching the entire fast&furious franchise everyday for the rest of my life than rewatch this ridiculous wannabe art-movie.Spare yourself the pain.

If you aren't into surreal and enjoy a story, don't watch this one. I have no idea what it is about. All I can surmise is that it is a director's fantasy. It is a fantasy about what this film director would love to do to his actresses and also what this director would love to see. It's a film for David Lynch by David Lynch. The one redeeming quality is Naomi Watts' performance. Otherwise, "What The H....E.....double hockey sticks?" My film viewing time is too precious to be spent on this. I feel, as when I am waiting in a supermarket check out line, that I now know far too much about David Lynch. Other good things, good choice of setting in some scenes, but the slow pan and scan on doorways, mugs, and furniture are just too much. The key? Some personal meaning that only Lynch can understand.
The perfect film to sort out low IQs from high IQs.The majority of filmgoers is testament to why we can't have nice things, but they're not smart enough to realize it.
It's amazing how many people love not understanding a single thing in a movie and then search for the meaning in YouTube videos.

o m g , 2 and 1/2 hours gone . they wouldn't let me capitalize this as I wanted to for emphasis. this is a line thank god I didn't pay to see this. I don't think the director even knew what was going on. this movie had no direction. It wandered from the accident to the end. maybe the director had amnesia too. The girls were hot though and I appreciated the brief nudity. I need to add more lines which I guess is what the writer did in the movie. well i need more lines so i'll keep typing then there will come a time that the review will be better than the movie Boy this site is stupid it still is giving me errors for stuff which is long gone. This site is also so bad for posting something that it can not even see corrections or understand emphasis . But "never give up never surrender"

Seen this movie 6 times so far. I still am not sure what the HELL it is about and to be honest that is a major drawback. A lot of it strikes me as bizarre for the sake of bizarre. Yes there are some wonderful acting jobs in there and the fact that I can re-watch it so many times is a testament to the movie itself. However I have problems with directors whom feel that something is only art is the Philistines don't get it. To have a movie where you can watch it repeatedly and STILL not know what it is about... just strikes me as wrong. I know it got good reviews from the powers that be but It just didn't work at all for me. To much strangeness for its own sake

Review title: Wake me up when the credits run
Review_body: I suppose i might have liked the movie... but i didn't bother watch the whole thing. If i needed anymore stress i'd try to find logic in FLCL. The whole thing's just one "artistic" (note the quotes) blur.I could care less of how Lynch fused every damn element into this flick... since in the end, it was one word, horrible. Call me what you will, narrow-minded, or what-not. Even though i understood the damn thing, i still say it sucked.But you have got to WATCH THE MOVIE. I'm not saying it's great, it's more like a train wreck... horrible, yet intriguing. People have different views on certain things, so I still suggest viewing the film... even if it might seem like a total waste of money, afterwards.

This is one of the worst, most pretentious movies ever made. No coherence of plot what so ever. People like to discuss what things really meant in the movie which is futile because NOTHING REPRESENTS ANYTHING. This isn't a deep movie at all. I can't say how much I was taken back when with 45 min of movie time left the director decided that everything up until that point in the movie would be reversed with a lesbian scene and some lightning strikes. That isn't film making. Another truly amazing turn in the movie came with the two inch tall senior citizens crawling under the door for absolutely no reason. which made me say "You have got to be efing kidding me!". David Lynch is an awful movie maker who seemingly feels that an incomplete script and plot twists from way out in left field constitute a good film. In the end all you have here is an un-enjoyable, self indulged pile of 35 millimeter dung.

Review title: A Lynchean puzzle of karma exchange with his surrealism and puzzle-like style
Review_body: This is a movie I watched a long time ago when I it felt like an unsolvable puzzle. It may be still be. Lynch says he's got a good idea and then breaks the rules.Mulholland Dr. is an amazing discovery of the value of good and bad karma and its randomness. It's also a movie about false dreams within a dream.Have fun exploring it :) I won't say more.

Review title: Mullholland Dr in short was confusing
Review_body: The only reason I even gave two stars was Naomi Watts portrayal in her test screening. She could have gone either way there and she pulled it off. David Lynch's vision was atrocious!! The story line was all over the place. When the 'mystery blue box' is dropped, the characters change names. The sex scenes weren't even warranted. 'Betty' is familiar with 'Rita' for one day, and they have lesbian sex....AND Betty proclaims her love!!! Outrageous! The cowboy, now who is he? No reason to throw him in. The gentlemen in the restaurant...unnecessary. Then I see on one review it got 3 out of 4 stars. WORTHLESS! I read a review earlier. Quote 'A waste of two hours of my life' unquote.

The movie was going in a interesting way until Rita/Camilla open the blue box, then suddenly change the entire story and what happened I just didn't understand. I am not that much genius to understand this plot, but somehow I strongly recommend to watch this most captivating thriller.

This was the third or fourth David Lynch movie that i have seen, and i have no idea the allure he has over people.  When i was watching this movie, i felt he was trying too hard to confuse people.  And he didn't try to confuse people with artful direction, or a well designed script.  His main tactic for confusion was using pronouns.  Throughout the movie people are referred to as him, her, they, and it.  Mind you, i know that pronouns are used all the time, but, he uses them when a name would be the more natural form of speaking about someone.  If you want confusion, there are so many other movies that will really twist your mind.

Review title: How can anyone like this movie?
Review_body: This movie was absolutely horrible.  It didn't have a plot, nothing made even a small amount of sense... and what was up with the stupid blue box? I strongly believe that anyone who claimed to like this movie either: 1) Think because it is confusing that it therefore must be intelligent, and have a purpose or 2) Are a teenage boy who just liked the lesbian fantasy scenes. Mulholland Drive is neither intelligent (Lynch just threw it together, and if you think otherwise, you're fooling yourself), nor interesting.  I think David Lynch owes me the 2+ hours of my life that was wasted wading through his garbage.

Review title: My views on why Mulholland Drive is a hair-raisingly good movie
Review_body: There's a sign on The Lost Highway that says:*MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD*(but you already knew that, didn't you?)Since there's a great deal of people that apparently did not get the point of this movie, I'd like to contribute my interpretation of why the plot makes perfect sense. As others have pointed out, one single viewing of this movie is not sufficient. If you have the DVD of MD, you can "cheat" by looking at David Lynch's "Top 10 Hints to Unlocking MD" (but only upon second or third viewing, please.) ;)First of all, Mulholland Drive is downright brilliant. A masterpiece. This is the kind of movie that refuse to leave your head. Not often are the comments on the DVDs very accurate, but Vogue's "It gets inside your head and stays there" really hit the mark.David Lynch deserves praise for creating a movie that not only has a beautifully stylish look to it - cinematography-wise, has great   acting (esp. Naomi Watts), a haunting soundtrack by Badalamenti, and a very dream-like quality to it -- but on top of it all it also manages to involve the viewer in such a way that few movies have before. (After all, when is the last time you saw a movie that just wouldn't leave your mind and that everyone felt compelled to talk and write about, regardless of whether they liked it or hated it?)Allright, enough about all that, it's time to justify those statements.Most people that have gone through some effort to try to piece the plot together will have come to the conclusion that the first half of the picture is an illusion/a dream sequence.Of course, that's too bad for all those trying to make sense of the movie by expecting "traditional" methods in which the story is laid out in a timely, logic and linear manner for the viewer. But for those expecting that, I urge you to check the name of the director and come back again. ;)MD is the story of the sad demise of Diane Selwyn, a wannabe-actor who is hopelessly in love with another actor, Camilla Rowles. Due to Diane's lack of talent, she is constantly struggling to advance her career, and feels she failed to deliver on her own and her parents' expectations. Upon realizing that Camilla will never be hers (C. becomes engaged with Adam Kesher, the director), she hires a hitman to get rid of her, and subsequently has to deal with the guilt that it produces.The movie first starts off with what may seem as a strange opening for this kind of thriller; which is some 50s dance/jitterbug contest, in which we can see the main character Betty giving a great performance. We also see an elderly couple (which we will see twice more throughout the movie) together with her, and applauding her.No, wait. This is what most people see the first time they view it. There's actually another very significant fact that is given before the credits - the camera moving into an object (although blurry) and the scene quickly fading out. If you look closely, the object is actually a pillow, revealing that what follows is a dream.The main characters seen in the first half of the movie:Betty: Diane Selwyn's imaginary self, used in the first half of the movie that constitutes the "dream-sequence" - a positive portrayal of a successful, aspiring young actor (the complete opposite of Diane). 'Betty' was chosen as the name as that is the real name of the waitress at Winkies. Notice that in the dream version, the waitresses' name is 'Diane'.Rita: The fantasy version of Camilla Rhodes that, through Diane's dream, and with the help of an imaginary car-accident, is turned into an amnesiac. This makes her vulnerable and dependent on Diane's love. She is then conveniently placed in Betty/Diane's aunt's luxurious home which Betty has been allowed to stay in.Coco: In real life, Adam's mother. In the dream part, the woman in charge of the apartment complex that Betty stays in. She's mainly a strong authority figure, as can be witnessed in both parts of the film.Adam: The director. We know from the second half that he gets engaged with Camilla. His sole purpose for being in the first half of the movie is only to serve as a punching bag for Betty/Diane, since she develops such hatred towards him.Aunt Ruth: Diane's real aunt, but instead of being out of town, she is actually dead. Diane inherited the money left by her aunt and used that to pay for Camilla's murder.Mr. Roach: A typical Lynchian character. Not real; appears only in Diane's dream sequence. He's a mysterious, influential person that controls the chain of events in the dream from his wheelchair. He serves much of the same function as the backwards-talking dwarf (which he also plays) in Twin Peaks.The hitman: The person that murders Camilla. This character is basically the same in both parts of the movie, although rendered in a slightly more goofy fashion in the dream sequence (more on that below).Now, having established the various versions of the characters in the movie, we can begin to delve into the plot. Of course I will not go into every little detail (neither will I lay it out chronologically), but I will try to explain some of the important scenes, in relation to Lynch' "hint-sheet".As I mentioned above, Camilla was re-produced as an amnesiac through her improbable survival of a car-accident in the first 10 minutes of the movie, which left her completely vulnerable. What I found very intriguing with MD, is that Lynch constantly gives hints on what is real and what isn't. I've already mentioned the camera moving into the pillow, but notice how there's two cars riding in each lane approaching the limo.Only one of the cars actually hit the limo; what about the other? Even if they stayed clear of the accident themselves, wouldn't they try to help the others, or at least call for help? My theory is that, since this is a dream, the presence of the other car is just set aside, and forgotten about. Since, as Rogert Ebert so eloquently puts it "Like real dreams, it does not explain, does not complete its sequences, lingers over what it finds fascinating, dismisses unpromising plotlines."Shortly after Rita crawls down from the crash site at Mulholland Dr., and makes her way down the hillside and sneaks into Aunt Ruth's apartment, Betty arrives and we see this creepy old couple driving away, staring ghoulishly at each other and grinning at themselves and the camera. This is the first indication that what we're seeing is a nightmare.Although the old couple seem to be unfamiliar to Betty, I think they're actually her parents (since they were applauding her at the jitterbug contest). Perhaps she didn't know them all that well, and didn't really have as good a relationship with them as she wanted, so the couple is shown as very pleasant and helpful to her in the dream. They also represent her feelings of guilt from the murder, and Diane's sense of unfulfillment regarding her unachieved goals in her life.A rather long and hilarious scene is the one involving the hitman. Diane apparently sees him as the major force behind the campaign trying to pressure the director to accept Camilla's part in the movie (from Adam's party in the second half of the movie), and he therefore occupies a major part of her dream. Because of her feelings of guilt and remorse towards the murder of Camilla, a part of her wants him to miss, so she turns him into a dumb criminal.This scene, I think, is also Lynch's attempt at totally screwing his audience over, since they're given a false pretence in which to view the movie.Gotta love that 'Something just bit me bad' line, though. :)The next interesting scene is the one with the two persons at Twinkies, who are having a conversation about how one of them keep having this recurring nightmare involving a man which is seen by him through a wall outside of the diner that they're sitting in. After a little talk, they head outside and keep walking toward the corner of a fence, accompanied of course by excellent music matching the mood of the scene.When reaching the corner, a bum-like character with a disfigured face appears out from behind the corner, scaring the living crap out of the man having the nightmare. This nightmare exists only in Diane's mind; she saw that guy in the diner when paying for the murder. So, in short, her obessions translate into that poor guy's nightmares. The bum also signifies Diane's evil side, as can be witnessed later in the movie.The Cowboy constitutes (along with the dwarf) one of the strange characters that are always present in the Lynchian landscape -- Diane only saw him for a short while at Adam's party, but just like our own dreams can award insignificant persons that we hardly know a major part in our dreams, so can he be awarded an important part in her dream. We are also given further clues during his scenes that what we're seeing is not real (his sudden disappearance, etc.)The Cowboy is also used as a tool to mock the Director, when he meets up with him at the odd location (the lights here give a clear indication that this is part of a dream). Also notice how he says that he will appear one more time if he (Adam) does good, or two more times if he does bad. Throughout the movie he appears two more times, indicating to Diane that she did bad. He is also the one to wake her up to reality (that scene is probably an illusion made to fit into her requirements of him appearing twice), and shortly thereafter she commits suicide.The espresso-scene with the Castigliane brothers (where we can see Badalamenti, the composer, as Luigi) is probably a result of the fact that Diane was having an espresso just before Camilla and Adam made their announcement at Adam's party in the second half. It could at the same time also be a statement from Lynch.During the scene in which they enter Diane's apartment, the body lying in the bed is Camilla, but notice how she's assumed Diane's sleeping position; Diane is seeing herself in her own dream, but the face is not hers, although it had the same wounds on the face as Diane would have after shooting herself. This scene is also filled with some genuine Lynchian creepiness. Since Diane did not know where (or when) the hitman would get to Camilla and finish her off, she just put her into her own home.In real life, Diane's audition for the movie part was bad. In her dream, she delivers a perfect audition - leaving the whole crew ecstatic about her performance.Also interesting is the fact that the money that in real-life was used to pay for Camilla's murder now appears in Rita/Camilla's purse. This is part of Diane's undoing of her terrible act by effectively being given the money back, as the murder now hasn't taken place.When her neighbor arrives to get her piano-shaped ashtray, another hint is given; she takes the ashtray from her table and leaves, yet later when Camilla and Betty have their encounter on the couch, we see the ashtray appear again when the camera pans over the table, suggesting that Betty's encounter with the neighbor was a fantasy.The catch phrase of the movie Adam is auditioning actresses for is "She is the girl"; which are the exact same words that Diane uses when giving the hitman Camilla's photo resume.The blue box and the key represent the major turning point in the movie, and is where the true identities of the characters are revealed. There's much symbolism going on here; the box may represent Diane's future (it's empty), or it may be a sort of a Pandora's box (the hitman laughs when she asks him what the key will open). Either way, it is connected to the murder by means of the blue key (which is placed next to her after the murder has taken place). The box is also seen at the end of the movie in the hands of the disfigured bum.Club Silencio is a neat little addition to further remind the viewer that what s/he is viewing is not real. It also signifies that Diane is about to wake up to her reality (her reality being a nightmare that she is unable to escape from, even in her dreams).During the chilling scene at the end where the creepy old couple reappear, Diane is tormented in such a way that she sees suicide as the only way out in order to escape the screams and to avoid being haunted by her fears.Anyway, that is my $0.02. Hope this could help people from bashing out at this movie and calling it 'the worst movie ever' or something to that effect, without realizing the plot.As usual, Lynch is all about creating irrational fears, and he certainly achieves that with this picture as well.10 out of 10.

Review title: Great, if you have the decoder ring
Review_body: "Mulholland Dr." reminded me of the first time I read "The Sound and the Fury;" it was just completely over my head and I hated it. But then I bought the Cliff Notes and everything seemed to make sense and I actually admired the book. "Mulholland Dr." is similar; when I finished the movie I was completely frustrated, but once I read an article that explained it, everything again seemed to make sense and I do admire the movie.However, I cannot help but feel that a movie that requires an outside source to make it enjoyable and meaningful is nothing more than a cheat. I am impressed with the film and Mr. Lynch's direction, but that doesn't make up for the feeling that he is trying to pull the wool over his audience's eyes. I am telling my friends not to see this film; if they absolutely must see it, I am telling them that they MUST find an article, a secret decoder ring of sorts, that explains it or they will be utterly disappointed.

Review title: start is OK, but then: overconstructed, post-predictable
Review_body: Mulholland Drive is based on constructions, and that's what we know at the end: the only thing what is left to expect, but doesn't happen, is Alfred Hitchcock walking by. I'm sorry, but real life seems to me a hundred times more exciting. Best regards, Johan Kelderman.

The worst film of the year is also the most pretentious pile of nonsensical crap I have seen in a very long time. People who adore this film only do so in a vain attempt to be cool and because they like to believe they are "above" other film-goers who believe in such mundane film concepts such as character/plot development. Don't be fooled, Lynch has no idea what he's doing and resorts to inserting cheap emotions (such as the admittedly hot lesbian sex scene) in place of real feelings. If you want to taste a sample of real cinema from last year, try "Ghost World" or "Waking Life" instead.

Reality is not linear.  Our reality is just a sum of hopelessly unreliable recollections of our perceived past, our hopes and fears of the future  all colored through the kaleidoscope of our subjective point of view  and all mixed together in a timeless and dimensionless sphere of our mind. Fragments of our experiences (already subjective as such) appear throughout this reality, but they shift and change with time.David Lynch attempts to capture this reality on film.Linearity is un-reality.  It is an attempt of our logical mind to take and order fragments of our thoughts and memories into a sequence that satisfies its own needs for simplicity, order and sense.  It picks and chooses, forms and transforms, censors, embellishes, exagerates these as it sees fit.Traditional american movies attempt to capture this un-reality on film. They are meant to make us escape reality, to satisfy our logical mind, our craving for simplicity and order.It is the process of dreaming that lets the mind untie these previously formed linear constructs, and re-order them, re-shuffle them, try different combinations, try fitting pieces together in different ways to make them fit our "current" reality more closely.  This can be driven by hopes or by fears, both making prominent appearances in Lynch's movies.In movies like Mulholland Drive or Lost Highway, Lynch tries to break down the linearity of our mind by showing us how the same pieces can be put together to form very different but still self-sustained logical linear worlds - which is very close to the process taking place during a dream.  I think this is why many people explain these as being dreams.----In many respects, Mulholland Drive is a big-budget version of Eraserhead (one of my favorite movies of all time)  Many of the same themes are repeated, as well as visual and plot elements.----I also think, that in some forms of art, one has to learn the language of the artist to be able to experience it (or at least more of it).  This is obviously true in literature (poetry for example) - and also to great extent in music (there are different musical "languages" - rules of forming rhythms and melodies, that at first might sound strange and alien, but once we get familiar with them, we often discover the real genius in the piece.)I think this is true for movies as well - seeing a David Lynch movie for the first time for someone used to conventional american cinema is like hearing jazz for the first time for someone trained in classical music, or hearing the alien beats and soundscapes of Richard James for the first time.Many of the elements that repeat in Lynch's movies are just elements of his artistic language.  While these in themselves are pleasing to look at (much like a foreign language poem might be pleasing for its rhythm and flow), it is what is being expressed using them that really completes the picture. It is not about getting the plot  it's about learning the language, to hear what is being said.  And this is also not so much a question of intellect, but more of effort and open mind.People who complain about the movie having no plot and not being interested in the characters are like people who see a movie in French and complain that the dialogues made no sense.

After seeing this movie yesterday I checked out IMDB to find out what this movie is all about. After reading all comments I still don't know. As far as I'm concerned it's a pretty good film except for the part where the moviemakers ran out of money and decided to make a cheap artmovie out of this plot. It's very surprising to see this movie gets an 8/10 from the viewers. Those voters must be very happy people who can stare at modern paintings for hours as well. Use your fantasy and make up the story yourself and...tell others you figured it all out. You're so smart and we're so stupid. I bet Mr. Lynch is having a lot fun right now; his viewers came up with answers he didn't even think about himself. This so called dream-flashback-mystery-flashforward-plotless-endless-lsdtrip-movie is a very convenient judgement for David (yehhhhh, I got away with it!). Please look at the movie some more times and give me more theories about what it is all about: keep on dreaming!

When I saw "Lost Highway," I feared David Lynch had lost his touch. "Straight Story" did nothing to allay my fears... even had I enjoyed that earnest, plodding slice of humdrum, it wouldn't have satisfied my craving for Lynchian weirdness. Well, he's back, in all of his red-curtained, menacing, mind-altering glory. I'm tempted to label this my favorite Lynch film. It's a pretty close second or third only to "Eraserhead" or "Blue Velvet". Bravo! Silencio!

Review title: Masterpiece, one of Lynch's best films
Review_body: Á deep dark mystery, what Lynch does best. It builds and builds and then collapses about 2 3rds into the film, after which it's structure morphs into something different (and even more mysterious.), contains some brilliant acting and sadly also some only watchable acting, a brilliant score by Angelo Badalamenti, the movie will be a big surprise even for those who read the screenplay back when it was a tv pilot.

In a few words, i found the movie to be very surprising, and one can think hours about the real intention D. Lynch had with this story. I hope I figured it out, not sure though. It was a great movie, one of the best on video I've seen this last year.

"Mulholland Drive" is closer to the "Lost Highway/Fire Walk With Me" Lynch than it is the "Blue Velvet/Wild At Heart" Lynch.  Which is a shame because so many casual viewers of his work will likely be unable to penetrate the goings on of this latest film.  A common complaint I have heard is that Lynch tells an interesting tale in Mulholland Drive but goes off the rails in the last 20 minutes and "just gets weird".  But it's these last 20 minutes that throws the preceding 2 hours into a perspective that you wouldn't suspect, and you realize that the story you've been watching up until that point is... well, I won't give it away.  Suffice to say that with a lacklustre summer behind us, it's reassuring that there's filmmakers out there who still take risks.

So what is it people see in David Lynch, the man himself doesn't know what his movies are about. He should be french, his movies are. Mulholland drive begins boring, and so must have noticed the author/director. Because suddenly the people change names, and we get to see some sex...wow, that really saves a film. But not this one! When I see a movie I don't want to think about the meaning of this or that camera setting. I want to see an intelligent plot developing intelligently. Something that does not happen here. Everybody that loves this movie will love Bill Cosbys "Incoherency".

Review title: Where does it begin and end??
Review_body: Hitchcock would be proud of this movie.  Even when nothing happens, it is suspenseful.  Director David Lynch overuses a few cheap thrill tricks here and there, but he intersperses them with other cinematographic techniques to keep it from becoming obtuse.Altogether surreal, this movie is like waking up and remembering most of a dream but not enough to make it sensible.  I am still trying to figure it all out and will probably have to see it again to catch things I missed and which may help me understand it better.  It is a very detailed plot that very slowly comes together, so you must be patient and pay attention.  Get your bathroom trip out of the way before it starts.  And yet, the plot is overshadowed by the theme, the mood, the character development, and the filming techniques.The dual roles of the main actress, Naomi Watts, showcase her enormous talent.  That is, when I could get my eyes off of her co-star.  What an acting pair.Lynch surprises throughout the movie with unusual camera angles, the length/timing of editing cuts, jumping back and forth between scenes. Combined with smart use of music and sounds, it all helps to build suspense in our minds, doubtless a major objective of the director.  Well, he kept me on the edge of my seat, even had me talking to the actors to be careful here, and not be so naive there.  You know, the kind of stuff you want to smack your kids for doing at the movies.

Review title: Mulholland Dr. is and example of The Emperor's new clothes, Lynch is is thought to be a great film maker so this must be great. Wrong, terrible, story telling one of the worst films I've ever seen.
Review_body: "Mulholland Dr. is another one of David Lynch's films that starts slow and never gets up to speed, and goes nowhere. "Mulholland Dr." is a classic example of "The Emperor's new Clothes". Lynch is thought to be a great film maker so "Mulholland Dr." must be great, wrong. The film is awful story telling, and if I could vote less then 1, I would. The film is less then zero.

The music was excellent.  The acting was great, So why did the movie fall way short for me??? I guess after the great reviews, I thought this would be a movie to remember and it was but for the wrong reasons.  If you really need to watch this movie, do so with an open mind and think how much money it takes to make a project like this and also remember with the money that was spent on this project we could have made some low income homes across our nation or how about take some of the money and feed our people with food and not garbage.  But thats another story. 5 out of 10 only for the music and acting.

I consider myself a highly intelligent guru of movies. That said, Mulholland Dr. failed. I found myself wishing the movie was over as I sat and watched as confusing, non-sequential scenes played out before my eyes. The movie seemed to end at a total random point and left me regretting the moment I selected it at Blockbuster Video. Spare yourself the 2 hours and don't rent this movie. This movie is going through "the emperor's robe is beautiful" phase right now. Everyone is embarrassed to say that the movie made no sense and that it was awful. This conclusion is however the only reasonable one that can be drawn.

it's hard to say that your favorite director has made a movie like 'mulholland drive'. boring in the first part, the last work of david lynch looks like a stylistic exercise, an useless and self-celebrating repechage of his classic features. a mysterious dwarf and a dark lady without memory are not enough to show lynch's ability. the same circular structure used in 'lost highways', but without the same intensity. what a pity!my vote: 6 (i can not believe it!!!)

Before I start, I want to say I loved...*loved*...this film.  It was the first Lynch film I've seen, and I was thoroughly impressed.  It was most certainly the most enthralling, entertaining movie I've seen this year.Anyways, I have a theory about what it means.  This is just my interpetation, and I'm most likely wrong.  But, I think there is no correct answer to what a film like this means.  This interpetation is just what I would like the movie to mean.  I think that that the first part of the movie represented the kind of movie that most audiences would like to see.  A mysterious beginning followed by a detective story to keep the pace. The main characters are a successful, beautiful actress and a up-and-coming, beautiful actress from Canada. In between, we have humorous scenes such as the director with his golf club and the bungled hit on the man with the "black book".  It culminates in a love scene between the main characters, and a trip to the theatre.  It my opinion, this trip to the theatre is the key to the entire film.  The recorded music represents "perfection", or what we would like to hear.  Tapes can be edited and re-done so that the music does not have the slightest imperfection.  The woman singing that wonderful song faints in the middle of it, revealing to the audience the true nature of the music.  Notice the theater is called 'Silencio' and that the last word in the film is the same.  The point here is that sometimes perfection is misleading, and that silence is a better option.  I'm not sure if I want the silence to mean just silence and facing reality, or if I want it to mean death.  The death idea would make sense because we can interpret the old people from when we first see Betty that were smiling and laughing as a sign that they are eagerly awaiting the silence and destruction of the attempts of "perfection" in life.  Obviously, the second story featuring Diane is anything but perfect.  It represents reality, and unfortunatley reality is very far from being perfect.  We see the fall of Diane and her relationship with Camille.  In the end, she is stalked by the laughing old people we saw earlier and Diane kills herself out of desperation.  Again, I'm not sure if I want her death to symbolize the affects of trying to reach perfection in life or for it to be Diane realizing that death is the only way to silence society's pressures of "perfection".  All I know is that I was profoundly moved by the movie, and my immediate reaction was that I didn't know why I was so moved and that maybe it was too deep to verbalize.  Although I've obviously tried to verbalize my thoughts on it, I think that Lynch has somehow created something that is impossible to emotionally describe in it's entirty.

Review title: What the hell is this about?
Review_body: Had it not been for the lesbian scene, I would have given this film a rating of 1. You have to be a mind reader to follow what is happening.  Several scenes have little if any relevance to the razor-thin plot.  A touch of character development could be warranted, but since dialogue is non-existent, how could they be developed.  The entire script could be no thicker than a 25 cent comic book.  And what's up with the blue box?Wow, what a stinker!  Can somebody explain it to me Lucy.

If David Lynch's Mulholland Drive is going to do anything, it will confuse the hell out you.  In all likelihood, most who exit the cinema will wonder, was that a very weird film, or was it an incredibly bizarre dream?Originally intended as a television series, Mulholland Drive was cancelled shortly after the pilot was made.  Not wanting to let his dream die, Lynch added some new scenes converting it into a feature length movie.  Because it began as a television series, a number of affairs remain unresolved.  But after seeing what Lynch has managed to create with what little he had, this is forgivable.The film reeks of Lynch's earlier work.  In fact, this one acts almost as a show reel of its predecessors.  Some fantastic camera pans and lush music make appearances here, which are now Lynch staples.  To boot we have the usual dark settings and bizarre characters.  We're also treated to a narrative that decides upon changing directions somewhat.  In fact, after a time it basically allows another story with new characters - or are they? - to take the helm.The film depicts the move to Hollywood of an aspiring actress named Betty Elms, played by Naomi Watts.  She is the starry-eyed small town girl who, upon arrival meets Rita (Laura Harring).  Rita had been a woman by the name of Camilla Rhodes, but suffered amnesia after being involved in a car accident before she could be murdered.  Betty decides to help Rita find her identity and, to put it mildly, the two become close friends.Sound complicated? There is more.  The film also plays host to a number of characters, all seemingly unrelated but connected in some way or another.The key theme here appears to be dreams, or some sort of notion of them. Not only does the film play out like a dream, but they are referenced frequently by characters.  A seemingly unimportant character at the beginning mentions that he would never want his recurring nightmare real. Betty on the other hand decides to make her ambition of movie stardom come true, following the cliché of the small town girl making good in Hollywood. However, this is a David Lynch film and dreams can quickly turn into nightmares.  Guess what? They do.The nightmares appear to be concocted by seemingly unrelated forces, in the form of bigwig movie producers and a very scary hobo.  These people, not only manipulate the casting of a film but the lives of those around them in an almost supernatural manner.For those unacquainted with David Lynch, Mulholland Drive would a good movie to start off on.   For those who have seen them all, well, there is not much new here.  Although there is some genuine comedy courtesy of a hapless assassin, and it is extremely well made.  If that is still not enough, at least Billy Ray Cyrus makes an appearance.

The acting and directing never looses a great script but I bet the script often looses the audience. Makes you think "what could it mean"? - then makes you not want to think what it could mean! One to buy for your collection.

I tell you this, I spoiled my evening and wasted my money on this psychopathic crap. First, the movie starts kinda boring and has no thrill in it. Then, when its finally getting to the end and you hope you'll get some clue of what was going on for 2 hours, things get more complicated. The movie ends with lots of screaming and madness, which isn't exciting at all. It ends leaving you wondering, what the hell happened after all?3/10, just coz it kept me in the theater waiting to the end.

Review title: Let's get this plot thing out of the way . . .
Review_body:
I think this is a masterpiece, but would not qualify as such if it had no coherent plot to it. WARNING: TOTAL SPOILER FOLLOWS-- DON'T READ ON UNLESS YOU'RE ONE OF THOSE WHO THINKS THE STORY MAKES NO SENSE, AND HAS NO DESIRE TO WORK AT FIGURING IT OUT. It is possible that once you see the story for what it is, you can open up to the rest of the delights this film has to offer.
There seems to be a lot of confusion about the plot-- even among the professional reviewers-- and much talk about how "one sees what one wants to see" but the actual plot is quite clear and definite once you unravel it: Two aspiring actresses show up in Hollywood at the same time (the blonde, Diane, after having won a jitterbug contest in Canada). They meet while making the rounds of auditions and become friends, even fall in love with each other and have sex-- only the black-haired one (Camilla) is much more successful at landing acting jobs and eventually drifts away from the blonde until the culmination at a party on Mulholland Drive where she announces she's marrying her director. The blonde can't take both her failure to find work and the complete rejection and has her ex-lover killed, then kills herself out of guilt and despair.Confusion arises in the viewer because virtually the entire first part of the movie (more than 80 percent of its running time) is a fever-pitch nightmare had by Diane which, in the fashion and with the "logic" of dreams, revisits this story but in a desperate, wish-fulfillment mode, in which she (as Betty) is talented, successful and in control of her relationship with Camilla (as Rita) who, by virtue of her amnesia, is the needy one. A very critical point to understand is that the dream occurs after Diane has paid for the hit on Camilla and before she awakens to find that it has been carried out. The dream is her last desperate attempt to arrive at some meaning and beauty in her life; it is also quite funny and prodigiously inventive. The dream's frantic re-casting of facts to protect what is left of Diane's decimated self-esteem-- often displaying a profound comprehension of the true horror and absurdity of Hollywood in its bizarre characters and incidents-- is the source of much of its humor. In this nightmare, "Betty" achieves the success she longed for in real life, and the admiration of "Rita" and many others, including Adam Kesher. In the course of MULHOLLAND DRIVE, the dream begins before the titles-- right after the opening jitterbug sequence, when the camera zeros in on Diane's bed and pillow. (Note that the strange older couple-- who I take to be Diane's proud parents-- appear in the jitterbug sequence.)The nightmare ends only at the point where Diane awakens to her neighbor's pounding at her front door. At this point, Camilla has been killed (see blue key on coffee table-- but I'm not going into all those details-- find them yourself, using Lynch's "ten clues".) At this point Diane has only a few hours to live. From this point the movie gives us at least one hallucination (Diane sees Camilla standing there before making coffee) and a hallucinatory flashback (the ensuing scene with Camilla on the sofa) but for the most part this final section serves to give the viewer the "straight story" of what really happened, using normal (shall we say, "objective") cinematic flashback narrative to bring it up to date. Keep your eyes and ears open and you will find many of the faces, names, locations, incidents-- snippets of reality that popped up in the nightmare, in the normal manner of our dreams. (The party at Adam Kesher's house is the greatest source of these-- keep in mind it is directly following this party that Diane arranges Camilla's murder, and has the nightmare that forms the bulk of the film.)At the very end we have one more hallucination of Diane's, as her parents reappear as mad demons, assaulting her with the horror of her failures, her guilt and her total degradation. In the panic that ensues, her only perceived escape is to shoot herself dead.Take it from there-- there are many wondrous layers to be explored in this film.
David Lynch's 10 Clues to Unlocking This Thriller:
Pay particular attention in the beginning of the film: at least two clues are revealed before the credits.Notice appearances of the red lampshade.Can you hear the title of the film that Adam Kesher is auditioning actresses for? Is it mentioned again?An accident is a terrible event... notice the location of the accident.Who gives a key, and why?Notice the robe, the ashtray, the coffee cup.What is felt, realized and gathered at the club Silencio?Did talent alone help Camilla?Notice the occurrences surrounding the man behind Winkies.Where is Aunt Ruth?

By far the most confusing movie I have ever watched.  I still don't know what happened.  Did I need to be taking acid in order to understand this? Was the blue box a whole new dimension, a dream, or was the first two hours of the movie a dream which became reality once inside the blue box?  This whole review could be filled with question marks, because I definately failed to get the jist of this one.  If it means that I'm uncool in the movie world for hating this movie, I'll take that title any day over watching it again.

Review title: First time: confusing. Second time: Genius.
Review_body: The first time I watched the movie, I wanted to like it because I am such a big Lynch fan, but although I enjoyed it, I thought it was simply weird for weird's sake with no method to the madness.Then I read the 10 clues given in the IMDB trivia section.  I watched it again the same day, trying to find the answers to the clues, and by the end of the movie I realized that it was pure genius.The movie makes perfect sense.  (95% of it anyway).  You simply have to figure it out.  So many movies try to send you home happy and ruin the mystery of the film.  Not Lynch.  He sends you home confused and then lets you experience the joy of figuring out the meaning of the movie.  It is there if you are willing to look.  If you need some help, go to Salon.com and search for Mullholland Drive.Make sure you understand this magnificent film before you start bashing it for being weird.

I thought this movie was about a doctor named Mulholland, I was sadly mistaken. Expecting a humorous medical comedy I entered the cinema with high hopes I left a dejected wreck of a human being as my soul had been shattered by this film and its: poor acting; lack of Dr Mulholland; over political agenda and chimp operated cameras.Whatever you do, do not see this film do not buy this film as a gift for loved ones and I encourage violence (or at least angry letters) against those responsible for this film.Bring back Dr Mulholland!

Review title: I get the movie, the plot, everything and it's still bad...
Review_body: You know why? Because it's pointless...it just is. The idea to split the movie in two "realities" actually is creative and a great cinematic moment but beyond that... What's the point of all this mess? Seriously, an aspiring actress who doesn't make it in Hollywood and falls in love with a intriguing brunette which also happens to be the love interest of the director that probably rejected her? Really, that's all you got? Nope, all artistic skills aside this movie is plain pointless and boring...there's nothing you take away from after you're done except for the feeling of having wasted your time...

Never seen in my life, a film like this before.. Absolutely perfect. Of a kind that opens your mind. Of a kind that apart from entertaining, offers lots of hint to think, and think in a way that you haven't done before. Did you have? It is a totally different, innovative, amazing, unbelievable film. David Lynch is a genius. If you haven't still seen the movie, you have to see it to understand what I exactly mean. "It's all an illusion!!" "Do you believe a man's behavior determines his life?" And what about your life? Which certain behavior and choices have determined or will determine your life? "We don't stop here!" Where you in the wrong place the wrong time? "My name is RITA?" Would you prefer sometimes to forget who you were, what you had done and become someone else? Would you prefer, sometimes, to be someone else? Someone like Rita Hayworth? Have you regretted for your choices?? Oh, yes! It's all an illusion. That's not the reality. This is not, what you thought it was!! This is completely something totally else!! "We wish you all the luck of the world with you!" And where did the luck gone?? It went to Rita who probably stole your dreams...and left a small second part/role for you! You choose which reality you will live? Which you like most? What about behavior? What about conformism? What about " I sense trouble?" What about a strange key? Will you keep it? What about the fear in front of an illusion, in front of a big lie? What about meanings?That's how I sensed this unique film.. I highly recommend it as a masterpiece of a kind! Gina K.

Review title: Insight in (what appears to be) a fragile young girl's mind
Review_body: A movie that demands a lot of it's viewer.The plot centers around two girls meeting each other: one young wannabe actress - who has just arrived to LA from Canada - and a brunette who has amnesia after a car crash. Anyway - soon you will begin to realize that only some of the events of the movie is what have happened and the rest is more or less fictional.I consider a young girl's refusal to accept reality as (the outstanding) main theme of the movie.Reminds me of Memento (2000) but this one is even more mind twisting.9/10 (my highest). Only 1 bad thing: I had to see it more than once.

Review title: worst 2.25 hour experience in some time
Review_body: This movie has dramatic value, interesting writing, & cinematography...  yet it still is able to SUCK beyond all expectation. No amount of re-editing could resurrect any film this poor.  perhaps the money would have better been spent assisting mobsters or other law-breakers in doing their business... at least that would have social signifigance, & would be entertaining to someone.

before i start i have to say one thing. You HAVE to watch this movie twice. The first time i saw it i understood absolutely nothing of what was going on. I was blown away and i kinda HAD TO watch the movie again. Because i needed to understand it. But as i said i understood almost nothing of the film the first time. The second time though, i discovered a lot of clues and saw different things that could help me unsolve the riddle. It is impossible'to solve the mystery completely. And every viewer will come up with their own conclusions. And that is what makes this movie so great. The characters are great, the actors are great (the acting starts a little dull, but it is all done for a reason)the camera angles everything. I have seen this movie about 4 times or something like that and it is definitely the best riddlesolving movie and it is actually as good as other classics like memento, the usual suspects and donnie darko.p.s i have to say, this movie IS NOT for everybody. If you are the kind of person who love going to the cinema to watch the new American pie movie, don't watch this film. But if you like a good mystery this movie is amazing

I discovered Lynch from Twin Peaks episodes. By the way, it's 30th anniversary of those episodes today. And the Mullholand Drive was his first film I watched. I'll never forget those emotions: it's 3 hours long and the first 20 mins I was struggling with the desire to turn it off. But starting from the 20th minutes something drastically changed and I got sticked to the screen. After watching it till the end I realized that I understood nothing from it. I started rewatching it from the beginning. I took me 6 hours on watching it back and forth, and another week to understand what I watched. In the end I came across with an article that said there are 10 hints to the film. But it's was not enough. You can watch it many times (what I did) and find something new each time. I recommended it to all of my friends, now I recommend it to you. Find 3-4 hours and try to understand what is it about .

Review title: The culminating work of David Lynch
Review_body: I'm a huge fan of director David Lynch and I really like his movies, especially Blue Velvet and EraserHead. But Mulholland Drive I think it takes all the surreal and dreamlike elements that I have mentioned and goes up one more notch. Love it.

Review title: The dumbest movie I've ever seen.
Review_body: I did not like this movie at all.  It started off alright, I was even tense as the plot unfolded.  But the longer I watched the more ridiculous it became. The longer it went on, the more ridiculous it became.  Too many characters were introduced that had no relevance to the story. The plot was shaky, erratic and just plain bizarre.  I honestly believe that David Lynch puts garbage together, slaps his name on the box, and laughs as everyone tries to figure out his montage of nothing.  I truly appreciate movies that are unique and take chances but this was a giant waste of my time.  All of the poetic eccentrics will say that those who didn't like this movie are too dumb or lazy to figure it out.  The fact is that this movie was a joke and I can't believe that it landed David Lynch an Oscar nomination.

Review title: Rated R for some strong sexuality
Review_body: Well, that sums it up: "some strong sexuality". Let's face it - the discussions about the meaning of Lynch movies are ridiculous. Probably Linch himself is laughing all the way when he stumbles over these silly attempts to make any sense out of his movies. Mulholland Drive fits the bill of excessive insanity perfectly. So why watch it at all? Honestly, I made the mistake to believe what thousands of critics said. My life would have been better without watching it. However, I guess it is not only the incredible stupidity of the plot why many become so enthusiastic about Mulholland Drive. It could very well be that "some strong sexuality" which entertains the perverts. Hey, you can watch a flick which is basically a cheap porn movie, and instead of feeling morally incorrect, you lie to others and especially to yourself that you have watched a "masterpiece". Avoid it at all costs.

Review title: The worst movie I have ever seen
Review_body: This movie has no plot, no direction, no nothing. It was long, slow and god awful. DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE! Seeing this makes me never in my life want to see another David Lynch film. It was the biggest waste of 2.5 hrs in my life.

I've seen it, 3 times in a week and I've still the curiosity of being absorbed again by the visionary Lynch's world. Don't believe people that will tell you that is boring or incomprehensible...it does make a lot of sense and you'll live a unforgettable trip for more than a couple of hours!!! If you desire movies that really leave you something and force you to reflect and analyze every detail, take a comfortable seat, turn the lights off and... have a good trip!!!**** POSSIBLE SPOILER ****An advice: after Rita opens the blu box and the second part of the movie starts, concentrate only on what you're going to see, don't try to remember the previous part, and DON'T MISS ANY DETAIL... you'll have a lot of time later to try to recompose the puzzle!!!My vote: 10/10
What a waste of 2 1/2 hours! This movie was one of the worst I've seen.

Review title: 2 and half hours of my life I will never get back
Review_body: After seeing this movie title on a few top 10 lists, I decided to force myself to watch this movie from beginning to end. I am a long distance athlete in both running and cycling but watching this through to the end was really challenging and I think I deserve a medal.Everything in this movie is slow, extremely slow. Some will describe it as being suspensefull but no, its just slow. From the beginning where the car is driving down Mulholland drive, barely going forward, all the way through to the end.The best part of the movie is the end (or should I rather call it the finish line) as that is the point where the suffering is over.To describe this movie - a very slow movie where all the females are lesbians, featuring a miniature grandma and grandpa who scares a lesbian into committing suicide as well as a sighting of the lesser seen Yeti in a dodgy alley.

I watched this movie because it was top of the 100 mystery movies list I was looking at. Mystic river was number 4 and that was very good, so I thought this being number 1 would be even better. I fell asleep 30 minutes in because it was so slow. The story line was terrible and the best part was the lesbian sex scenes. The rest was horrible. Doesnt make sense really. Did not hold my attention. Very sad. Even the cinematography and any symbolism was bad. 1/10, would not watch again ever. Does not deserve a 8 rating. Only good movies do.

Review title: This is probably the worst movie I've seen in years.
Review_body: There is no point to this movie. I will never get the time back I wasted watching this movie. Usually when I dislike movies, I just shake my head in disbelief. This movie actually made me want to get my money back. It was pure pointlessness, for pointlessness sake.

What is the point? Well, no one is really sure (maybe Lynch knows)... but the film seems to be about Hollywood's corruption of innocence and artistic integrity.Ok, if you'd like to make such a point, why do it in such a convoluted way? Well, apparently David Lynch thinks it's great art to leave the audience confused. That is, to make a film so surrealistic that there is really no logic, and therefor it leaves critics unable to attack the lack of structure in the story.It's really a worthless experimental piece. Much like the exploration of jazz music in the 60's that slowly peeled away the structure of music, to the point that one is left with incomprehensible and chaotic noise. Guess what? Random noise is not music ... and incoherent structure is not great art!Lynch spends a great deal of time developing interesting characters in the first half of the film. A comedic bent is shown with the hit man who has everything go wrong, and with the sinister cowboy Bob. But do these sub-plots go anywhere? No, they don't really... after Rita wakes up muttering "silencio", everything in the movie turns into a dream sequence. And all the sub-plots are tied together in a cursory and nonsensical way, as is often the case in a dream.Does nonsensical dreams make great art? I don't think so ... and neither does this movie.

Review title: An in depth look at a tortured soul
Review_body: David Lynch is an artist. Pure and simple. His most recent film MD is a beautiful look at such topics as jealousy, fear, love, hate and betrayal. The concept of a film as a perpetual mystery where the viewer is asked to explore the hidden meanings as opposed to "who did it" is a wonder to behold. I have read interpretation of the film ranging from a veiled blasphemy to a modern day rendition of the Wizard of Oz. I believe that Lynch requires an open mind and a superior intellect from his viewers if they hope to tap the arcane wisdom that his movies hold. Is Mulholland Dr. something that will appeal to everyone? No, and that is just fine. As long as Lynch enjoys what he is doing and has the respect of his peers and fans, everyone else can go pack the local multiplex to see the drool du joure.

Review title: A Masterpiece - Best film since American Beauty
Review_body: Mulholland Drive is David Lynch at his best. I do not want to discuss the specifics of how to interpret the film, but I will say that everything in the film serves a rational purpose. Although it may frustrate those who do not put forth the effort to try and understand it, those who do are sure to consider Mulholland Drive a director's masterpiece.

I voted this 10/10 like a month ago, i didnt feel a need to write a review for this, but this movie haunts me realy hard and i have a feeling that i fell in love with this, and also i have a feeling that i need to express my feelings about this because i am so tired of seeing people writing bad stuff about this movie.
Its totally fine having your own opinion about things and i rly dont mind people having bad opinions but.. when i see people writing how this is the worst movie ever, how it doesent make sense and how they actually were finding clues about this and answers and how it still didnt make sense fore them( saying also how they are clever guys..), or things like "what is the point about this movie when all was a dream", or pointless story that goes nowhere, or how only hardcore Lynch fans can like this.
This movie is actually the first movie i have ever voted. The first movie that i have ever felt a need to vote, because i just cant stop thinking about him. This for me makes movie so great, when you actually watch it and then you are keep thinking about it days, even weeks after, when you are crying couple of times because of him, when you almost every day listen to Angelo Badalamenti's track and feel gosebumps. Beleive me guys i think i have never been so in love with some movie like this one even if i watched a lot of movies.
I felt a need to create an account on imdb just to vote this 10/10, even if i knew about imdb and ratings and stuff, and was always on imdb checking out votes of movies.
When i watch a movie that have a straight forward basic story and there was nothing behind it, that is just not that good for me, i watch it and its over, no feelings, no needs, nothing. Maybe i have some kind of feeling for 1 hour, then its over, i am gonna probbably forgot about him after some time. Of course i am not gonna say that movies are bad, its just something is missing, something that exist here in "Mulholland drive".
And now for those people who i meontined before...
This movie actually make a perfect sense, i am not gonna explain it because there is already a lot of stuff on internet where you can actually find a great explanation of this, and also some user reviews here who actually explained good. Maybe you are not gonna find everything explained at the first place but that is not "0 sense". So stop saying how this makes no sense after you even try to find clues, because i just cant understand that.
What is the point of movie if all was a dream? Well.. the point is how Hollywood actors have their worst nightmares when they come there and how tragic their story ends. Their dream of success which represents the dream in this movie turn into their worst nightmare, and thats so sad, haunting, etc..
Only hard Lynch fans can like this? I am not a Lynch fan, i didnt even know who the director of this is when i watched this, i didnt even know that he exists.
Pointless story that goes nowhere?
As i said this movie makes perfect sense, and when you get it there is a story behind, and its not the bad story.
And yes, i forgot about someone saying "who gets this movie, they are only pretend they get it", please just make some effort to find an explanation for this.Cheers guys, great movie, i want to give it 11/10 but it doesent work.
10/10

Review title: David Lynch won Best Director at Cannes 2001 for this greatfilm!
Review_body: An interestingly thick and intriguing film which Lynch delivers in his true to form style of self-interpretive filmmaking. Don't expect Roger Ebert to like it (unless you hand him a tripledecker Ben & Jerry's Chocolate Chunk Sundae to eat while he watches it!). If you enjoy a higher form of film and don't mind having to think (god forbid) then this is a great work. Classic, and DEFINITELY SATISFYINGLY LYNCH.

Review title: One of the most mistrious movie i have ever seen
Review_body: The only recommendation i can give you is watch this great movie alone in the night to have a great pleasure with this such of masterpiece art, it's highly recommended for once who wants a surreal atmosphere and surreal scenario.
Disturbing and scary but neither disturbing or scary

Review title: Slow, confused, overly-hyped crap from male-dominated Hollywood
Review_body: Once a man such as David Lynch makes a name for himself in Hollywood he no longer has to create a movie that tells a story.  This movie is a confused, non-sensical combination of "thoughts" that was presumably admired by critics because of the beautiful filmmaking -- AND there is some beauty in this film that earned my 3 rating.  However, the slow-moving plot (?) crept along and tried my patience.  The lesbian sex scenes were well done, however, without being couched in a logical plot with some explanation, they came off as voyeuristic eye-candy that would unquestionably appeal to male-dominated Hollywood moguls.  This movie is not thought provoking.  You may find yourself talking about it the next day, but such conversations are NOT due to enjoyment and interested curiosity, but frustration and confusion.

Review title: Mulholland Drive is beyond a movie. It's a darkly magical Journey
Review_body:
I have watched MD at six or seven times during the last twenty years. I like to watch it anew every couple of years, and each time is a complex, exciting, highly-satisfying experience. For me it is the only film that is a round, perfect 10.Everything is amazing - the mysterious atmosphere, the vivid cinematography, the outstanding acting. Naomi Watts is no less than sublime in her role. She is very intense and succeeds in conveying this intensity in the most spectacular manner. This is a movie that makes you live with the characaters and Feel an array of emotions.It deals with jealousy, ambition, failure, love, insanity, guilt, total despair.The process is very fluid, tense and at times melancholic. The conclusion is tragic and scary in equal measures.Two scenes that are particularly remarkable for the emotions they evoke (in me, at least) and that I consider as among the most powerful in cinema are -
1) The guy in the diner with his shrink. He insists that at the backyard there's a monster, and he's awfully scared. The shrink then encourages him to go check the backyard together, to see for himself that there's no monster there. But when they do exactly that, a frightening figure suddenly peeks from behind the wall and briefly shows itself with a hideous smile. Upon seeing it, the guy loses consciousness on the spot.Interpretation - The moster is the darkest part of the subconscious, perhaps a terrible deed, a sin so horrific that the sinner cannot deal with it, thus it is well concealed in the back brain. But should the sinner confront it, stand in front of her/his secret with open eyes, s/he would not be able to take it, it would instantly kill them. (That, of course, what happened to Diane). In a wider sense, it doesn't have to be a sin. It could be any serious past trauma, devastating truth or great fear that maybe would better stay buried in the subconscious.2) The masturbation scene of Diane. It's one of the saddest, powerfully emotional scenes I've ever seen. Naomi Watts is brilliant here and the directing is genious too.In short, give yourself this special experience. Read the interpretations afterwards. Watch it again. I know that I surely will.

None of the actors and actresses played well. There are way better mysterious movies to watch. Not a good story. After watching, you may be able to guess 1 or 2 things. A lot would be unknown to even professionals and they need to read reviews for that. In every aspect of this movie, there is a better movie that's done and implemented it better and it's not good at anything. I watched it because it was David Lynch movie and I regret that.

Excellent movie - especially sitting with friends afterwards and trying to piece it together. There were also fascinating references to the movie industry as a whole (the cowboy episode) and to other movies (the diner scene was straight from Pulp Fiction ) which we had fun discussing. The drive home in the dark started the whole thing over again...

Review title: another great dream/nightmare film by David Lynch
Review_body: hi! french fan of David Lynch's universe, i've had the opportunity to see Mulholland Drive "en avant-première" in Paris july, the 4th.
