Review title: Mulholland Drive- the puzzler of puzzlers
Review_body: It is not often that films are both confusing and pleasing. Confusion is often reconciled throughout films in ways that leave viewers with a sense of finality and comfort with whatever theme that the filmmakers wish to convey. However, there are certain films that use irreconcilable plot incongruencies as a device that leaves an audience intentionally puzzled. The effectiveness and entertainment value of the movie is then even more dependent on the production and quality of the portions of the film that are coherent. David Lynch's film entitled Mulholland Drive is this sort of movie. Through it's ambiguous, disjointed plot yet superbly executed production, Mulholland Drive is a highly puzzling yet entertaining film. This critique intends to outline and analyze the aspects of the film that make it work.Without a coherent plot to depend on, Mulholland Drive places the onus of its quality on the value of each aspect of production. Through the usage of music, transitions, angling, and other film techniques, the movie manages to convey a message that stays consistent with the themes of the film that are discernible. The music manages to convey a sense of looming mystery and ominous foreshadowing in the low, constant tones. Even in the scenes where the characters are in broad daylight, like when the men are behind the restaurant or when the women are at Diane's apartment, the music compels the viewer to maintain a sense of tension and suspense. Another part of the film that enhances this feeling is the camera work. There is a strong presence of first person camera, which is another indication of the limited level of knowledge that the viewer is allowed. The blind corners and dark areas that are shown in this mode bring about an even greater sense of tension and even fear. Atop this camera effect technique is the hazy and disoriented transitions. This is consistent with the vagueness of the story as well as the memory of Rita (Camilla) that was largely lost after her accident. The combination of the music, camera perspective, and transitions translates into a riveting look inside the intense mystery that is centered around Mulholland Drive. With these tools, the viewer is drawn into a series of events that are disjointed and indiscernible yet enrapturing and highly entertaining.The plot is one of dizzying twists and curves that leave the viewer rather speculative. There are numerous possibilities as to what actually happened in the film that depend largely on the chronological order one sees the events in. It is possible that there are the three characters of Camilla/ Rita, Betty, and Diane that take on interchangeable aesthetic identities throughout the film by the main actresses Naomi Watts and Laura Elena Harding. It seems that there is also the possibility that Rita and Betty took on the alter identities of Camilla and Diane as time progressed after the accident. Another plausible plot involves Diane arranging the murder of Camilla then rekindling her love affair with "Rita" after the accident. Of course there are more possibilities that all seem possible, yet ultimately irreconcilable in any explicit way. This versatility is part of what makes this film worth watching again and again, and it is also one of the reasons that it was nominated for an Academy Award.The themes of this film are represented well through the symbolism of specific parts of the film. There is the dancing scene in the beginning with the multiple layers and reducing characters, which is symbolic of the cryptic nature of the plots and the dwindling memories of the film. There is also Silencio, the name of the place where the intriguing Spanish performance occurred. The oft spoken quote "no hay banda," or "there is no band," is another suggestion perhaps that reality is arbitrary and existence is not at all absolute or easy to discern. Certainly there are numerous ways to interpret the film, and this appears to be no accident on the part of the filmmakers' intentions. But the disorientation that the characters experience is transferred masterfully onto the viewer throughout the film. As far as puzzling movies go, this is extremely puzzling. However, this seeming disarray of events and themes is consistent in a way that is as confusing as it is riveting and ultimately entertaining.

Review title: A woman commits suicide and we she her final thoughts
Review_body: *** This review may contain spoilers *** Since I devoutly believe that brevity is king, and that simple is usually best...here is what this movie is all about.A woman commits suicide, and Mr Lynch then presents what is happening to the woman internally /neurologically.That is to say...Lynch shows us her last moments of sentience before oblivion takes her.The movie starts with the sound of the gun going off. This represents the woman "Betty Elms / Diane Selwyn" committing suicide with a gun. This happens off camera and off scene.The suicide is portrayed by the car crash in the opening scene. (The gunshot is heard during the crash scene.)We are then shown Betty / Diane basically review the personalities and choices of her life.As the neurons in her consciousness fire their last blips, her visions (which we see) get really weird. (i.e. her parents become tiny incomprehensible demon-like creatures.)The movie ends with the memory of the suicide. Betty / Diane shoots herself. Clouds of oblivion takes all...movie ends.That's the movie.It's a contemporary "Carnival of Souls".THERE! Now you understand "Mulholland Drive".Ronald Santos - David Lynch fan.

Review title: This movie should be watched with x1.5 speed
Review_body: The scenes are too tiring and slow going. Other than that, Naomi Watts is good, the other actress is a terrible actress. This is one of those movies you don't get along entire film, everything is very random, and you always think it will clear towards the end, but then the film is over and you have to google possible theories of what this film is about. Thumbs down.

Review title: Oh my, God!!! What a waste of film!!!! (Possible spoiler)
Review_body: I gave this one star because you can't go any lower than that here. I am reeling at the fact that I have wasted two and a half hours of my life watching this movie! It was chosen by my girlfriend, as a recommendation by her sister (who obviously needs to be beaten over the head with a bag of hammers and then shown some REAL cinematography). Needless to say, my girlfriend is NEVER allowed to pick out another movie. I have never felt so strongly about a movie as to write about it. However, this one warrants some warning to readers here who may not yet have seen this movie and are contemplating it. In two and a half hours, there are about 45 minutes of actual dialog. The movie moves at the pace of a pregnant snail with arthritis and a broken shell. Uphill. It is a great movie if you are suffering from serious emotional problems, or, are a suicidal lesbian, Hell-bent and glory bound to let you get the best of yourself. It could be said for anyone with a broken heart, not just suicidal lesbians. But, if you are unfortunate enough to encounter this trite little foray in to the disturbed workings of, what I can only presume is, a novice director, you'll understand what I mean. The cinematography was horrible. The shaking tends to lead one to run off for the nearest bottle of Dramamine. The characters are simplistic, predictable (though the plot is not...I'm sorry, did I say plot?) and, rather shallow. I have read better story lines from those exercises in 7th grade English class where one student starts a story, and passes the page to the next student, until it gets around the room. Imagine having 50 people get together. You tell one person something that is about 5 lines long. They repeat it to the next, and so on down the line. What you come out with, when compared to the original message is pure gibberish. Now...imagine applying the same concept to film. If you can do that, then, you have a better understanding of what this movie is going to be like for you. I think the safest thing to do, is take everyone who had anything to do with this movie actually being made (minus the actors, I realize that Hollywood is a tough business and sometimes, work is hard to find) were thrown in to a pit of rattle snakes, then, sent to a wading pool of hydrochloric acid, and then, sent skydiving over a feeding frenzy of great white sharks. Put it all on Pay Per View, and, you will be able to cover the expense of the viewers who are going to need therapy to figure out why they actually sat through more than about the first half an hour. Someone...PLEASE...get this message to the producer: STOP THE INSANITY!!!! I can't believe that a movie actually drove me to seek out a place to warn other people not to watch it. I thought Open Water was the worst movie ever made. Now...I know I was wrong. Oh, so wrong.

Lynch is the only director I've had the pleasure of viewing who - literally - can place the dreamscape onto film for others to view. We all get bored by those people who insist on sharing their intricate dreams with us, because they are long and dull for those who aren't involved. But also because dream logic is unstable, irrational, confusing - once you wake up. In Mulholland Dr., we care for the person dreaming, and care for her dreams.Mulholland Dr. is, like Twin Peaks in parts, a dream laid out on film. It is obscene for that reason - it is a private, unconscious moment made public and available. We share this film as voyeurs. This is a personal dream that makes me blush to watch - because we are not supposed to have this kind of insight into other people's psyche. But when you stop watching, like waking in those few moments from a dream, it all makes sense. When reality floods back, it still haunts.What a genius is Lynch - and what a master of dreams and nightmares.

Mulholland Drive is one of Lynch's best films by far. It is filled with everything you can ask for: action, horror, suspense, lesbian love scenes....Lynch is able to the viewer into this strange and bizarre world where we are never sure what is real and what is not. First time Lynch viewers should not expect something that makes complete sense, otherwise expect a major headache at the end. This movie forces the viewers to observe and develop their own conclusions about the story. Whether you love it or hate it, Mulholland Drive is an unforgettable, haunting movie. After seeing it for the first time, I could not get it out of my mind for the next week. When a movie has that much of a hold on you, you know it has effected you in some way. This movie is guaranteed to thrill you in some way, whether it be Lynch's unique storytelling, the great visuals, or mesmerizing soundtrack. This is a definite must for all Lynch fans as well as anyone else who is into surreal films. Those unfamiliar with Lynch's work might have a difficult time with this movie, but sometimes the best thing to do with this movie is just to roll with it. And make you watch it more than once, it's gets better the second time around since you can pick up on the the subtleties you missed the first time. Go see this movie!

Review title: A lot of nonsense! Messy and weird plot line. Finishing with the worse ending ever! WTF!?
Review_body: The only nice thing you're going to see is two ladies making out. I'd suggest you go watch an over 18+ movie instead.I will try to explain the inexplicable without spoiling, OK?First, you watch a nonsense story with a weird plot, a kidnapping car accident. You see some typical girls in L.A. trying to become famous and an amnesia girl who has no idea who she is. Then, suddenly they make love????? WTF?!Some hypnosis happening, people cheating, bad scary men....nonsense again.I think the worst bit (maybe spoiler coming) is a blue box. With a weird key, why the hell was it even in the movie???Oh! You might cry listening to the Opera concert...so emotional.To sum up, is that. You watch, and you watch, and you expect you'll understand the ending. However, even after reading all reviews and googling, you still won't know WTF the story is....yeah!Just waste your time to see some titties... But you better keep with the Wild Things for that. Much better story and titties too...
I was like "what?"!Naomi Watts is absolutely amazing though. Another David Lynchy David Lynch movie.

I had just seen it yesterday while paying attention to "David Lynch's 10 clues to unlock this thriller". It was my 3rd attempt. I will try to explain how the movie works for me. I think the first part of the movie is Diane Selwyn's dream (and some wishful thinking): Diane Selwyn played by Naomi Watts. Before the credits you can notice somebody facing his red cushion and sinking down. She (?) falls into sleep. Before Club Silencio, all the things going on seem to be a wonderful dream for her. Her goddess had an accident just as she was threatened by two cruel guys. Thus "Rita" (a dreamed character of Diane's female affair: Camilla Rhodes - played by Laura Harring) suffers a total loss of memory. The following story shows the wonderful life of Betty - Diane's alter ego. All you can see is remix of Diane's memory. The unusual story of lovely Betty and amnesiac Rita heightens straight up to its climax in the end of part 1. There is no aftershow in Club Silencio. Diane is waking up confronted with her present life... She is suffering the probable death of Camilla Rhodes - the woman she loves. Diane payed for the assassin. In the second part of the the movie you can notice details of Diane's life which are reflected in her dream. The plot jumps before and after her wakening up.Incidentally, while Betty and Rita are visiting Diane Selwyn in no.17, Diane dreams visiting her own burial together with a person who should regret.

Mullholland Drive starts very promising, and it really is the first hour and a half. If the film contained a little more blood, you could mistake it for a Tarantino film! But the ending is not good. I'm not going to reveal the story, but there are many, many questions that are not answered. If you have the choice, watch another film. Mulholland Drive is complete waist of time!Lynch can do better, he had proved it several times before, but with this "turkey", it would not surprise me if he's career is to it's end. The actors, though, are good. Thats the thing I enjoyed with the film. in fact, i would say that the acting overall is very good! So, is it really that bad? Well, don't take my word for it! If it's raining outside, and there is nothing else to do but watch Mulholland Drive, gather some friends and watch it. I'm sure you have something to discuss for an hour or two....

The blue box is, within her dream/coma/state of amnesia, a figment of Diane's imagination, representing that knowledge which she would like to uncover (her memory lost in the accident) which she has spent the first half of the film in search of. In the end, it is Betty that supplies her the key, aka, is that which lies at the center of her lost memories. Figuratively speaking, unlocking the blue box is Diane's way of pinching herself in order to wake herself up. And just as pinching one's self in a dream does not actually awaken one's self but is rather just a the part of the dream representing awakening, unlocking the box of course does not actually somehow restore Diane's memory, but merely represents in her dreaming mind the moment of her memory's restoration upon recovering neurologically from the accident. I'm pretty sure the field of psychology has a term for it, but I have no idea what it is...

Review title: great if you liked the movie Magnolia
Review_body: Sorry, but I like to be entertained by movies and not spend hours trying to tie all the loose ends together into something that seems logical. What did the director mean? I really don't care. This was a mishmash of subplots that made no sense whatsoever. There must be ten different explanations of the movie. I don't enjoy sharing idiotic interpretations of this waste of a movie. Apparently, there are a lot of people in this world that like to search for the symbolism and special meaning of the director. To me, this movie is a perfect example of what is wrong with Hollywood. As if you don't already know, the plot jumps back and forth between different scenarios and different time periods. I guess the coolest thing was the guy that played The Cowboy. I love the way he was dressed. It made no sense as he was totally out of place. Nevertheless, he was cool and it added to the weirdness.

I think most people try to put this movie together the wrong way.I also think more should have been explained by the movie but that's rotten tomatoes. This movie is made up of little things like colors, blue, red, etc, throughout the movie. I also believe everything is explained at Silencio. What you hear or see aren't necessarily the truth. Like when the cowboy told the director that he would see him once if he did good and twice if he did bad and we see the cowboy 2 more times. This movie is a rambling of a dream or nightmare laid out like a jigsaw puzzle except each person may see a different picture when they're done. It is done nicely but too deep to truly enjoy with a guest. There are better movies out there and this seems more like a cult classic. God Bless the USA!

It is reported that David's Lynch movie "Twin Peaks" is inspired by Marilyn Monroe's suicide and it's impact on people at that time.In my opion, I was able.to unravel a mystery.Mullholland Drive is about HOLLYWOOD, and is inspired by Fox Studios attempt to replace Marilyn by Jayne Mansfield.The Movie starts with an imitation of the opening of "GIRL can't help it".The name of the brunette is RIta. Jayne's name in her Broadway play was RITA MARLOWE. The blonde is the GIRl.And this movie start with a car accident.All ingrediences from Jayne's attempt to be someone else by replacing her, caused by her studio.
It's a masterpiece nd completely out of the box thing ..just enjoy watching this till the time u understood it completely

Review title: Been using this site for over a decade, never felt the need to write a review. Disgustingly bad movie
Review_body: Genuinely one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Ridiculously pointless. The first half was at least watchable even though it was pretty underwhelming for the most part.The last 40 mins or so were just ridiculous beyond belief lol. So, so stupid. I always go to this site, as I believe the ratings are reliable 90% of the time. This is one of the few times, they are definitely off, in my opinion.Would have given this movie a 1. Gave it a 3 cause of the brunettes tits. One more star for each magnificent tit.Again, don't think to yourself, you know what the rating is high, I might actually like it despite people saying it's a pointless and weird movie. You'll lose almost 3 hours of your life and perhaps your sanity.

Review title: An Eroded Fractured Art School Wreck
Review_body: This film is a dissociative. It's as though David Lynch magically captured the crumbling, unhinged conscious world on film as you descend into illness with influenza. You can smell the dry rot and with stale curtains. It's far from Lynch hitting the bullseye; it doesn't hit the dartboard or even the dartboard wall but hits the mat with precision. Forget gushy exhalations about cinematography masterpiece, this is a K-Hole of a film. Now in 2015 it has now eroded to leave a fractured art school wreck.1. It labours every camera angle leaving the viewer separated from the story, trapped in the mechanics of indulgent camera-work. It's worth remind yourself that the second you feel like this with any movie, a film is a failure.2. It is littered with bad production decisions. You can literally see the storyboards, the dressing of wardrobe mannequins as you are watching it, which become magnified by the cartoon character lead roles.3. The story's 'turning point' drowns the plot instead of unveiling it. 4. The lead girls magnetic looks eclipse the film entirely - I can imagine this was great for Lynch's pre-release meetings / investors / publicity office, but they are so visually intriguing to watch that the whole film spins off axis. You spend the film in a bubble of teenage sexual anxiety, as you plot wade, floating above the soup thick cinemaphotography on a raft of personal fantasy.5. Supporting actors and actresses are weak and uncharismatic, like the film production management meetings, the pathetic Woody-Harleson-a-like 'Cowboy' and let's not comprehend how the hell Billy Ray Cyrus ended up here other than a Lynch fulfilling a burbon addled Hollywood party promiseIt's not genius, it's indulgent, laborious, dated, eroded, film school rubbish.

Review title: MullHolland Dr. is only understood by understanding the play scene
Review_body: I haven't read all the comments so if someone has already pointed this out I apologize.In short, Lynch movies are designed to only be understood after a second, or a series of, re-watchings. First time I saw it I was confused. The second time, my mind was blown.Watts character killed the brunette out of professional jealousy. The amnesia in the beginning is really Watts' character remembering the brunette, but Watts is in a moment of shock and doesn't believe it just yet. The turn-around. Watts realizes what she's done at the theatre. If you notice the brunette woman singing on stage at one point falls dead but her voice continues. Just like the host says in the play. You hear a trumpet, yet there is no trumpet (notice how he seems to be looking at Watts character). Lightning begins to strike, Watts character begins to shake. She's remembering the truth. She's hearing and seeing what's not there......the brunette woman with amnesia.Now we see the brunette at the beginning in the car, going to a fancy party. The fact is, is that Watts character desperately wanted to make it in the movie business but is growing more and more jealous of her brunette counterpart. She hires the hit-man, that Lynch cleverly throws in at odd points early on to throw us a curveball, and has the brunette woman murdered (we even see the dead body early on when the two women are searching the mysterious house). The blue box and the key........Remember at the end how it is opened by the mysterious man behind the dumpster. The horrible truth is unleashed on Watts. Remember early on the story of the two guys at the diner who we never see again? The one guy with big eyebrows is talking about a dream he had of his friend and that there's a man behind the dumpster that's controlling everything. Well, when he finds the man behind the dumpster, that just indicates that the big-eyebrowed man has killed his friend that he saw in the dream. This of course parallels the whole theme of what happened in Mullholland Dr. Lynch movies are very intelligent actually. He's even said on an interview on the Blue Velvet DVD that he wants to make movies that REQUIRE repeated viewings. Quite clever of him. Now, if you want to see a Lynch movie that'll really twist your brain check out Lost Highway.

SPOILERS below!I think the movie is about the Underworld. Persephone, Hades, maybe Psyche. I can't figure out the Aunt Ruth thing. Maybe someone can help with that? The redheaded woman is dressed exactly the same when she hears the box fall as when she gets her keys and leaves. So either Rita dropped the box before the woman left, or the redheaded woman is a loop, like a ghostly figure??? Am I missing something? I know it's a "dream", but I think there's more to this "Ruth" part.here's my mythology explanations: http://qritiq.wordpress.com/2008/02/09/allusions-in-mulholland-drive/

Review title: The Perfect Representation of a Dream
Review_body: Mulholland Drive is arguably David Lynch's most well-known, recognized film. And this is for good reason: it's one of his few stories that makes complete sense. The widely held theory that the first four fifths of the movie is a dream that the character in the last fifth of the movie is having is the one that I subscribe to. It makes the entire story have a united plot, and ultimately, it makes rewatching it all the more tragic.A derelict, washed out actress named Diane Selwyn lusts for Camilla Rhodes, another actress who was thrust into fame by narrowly getting the lead role that Diane auditioned for. The two are friends, but Camilla is getting married to the director of her film, Adam Kesher. Diane, in a moment of anger, hires an assassin to kill Camilla. The night after Camilla has been killed, Diane has a dream of guilt in an attempt to rewrite the relationship between herself and Camilla. In her dream, she's a bright-eyed, ambitious newcomer to LA named Betty, and Camilla is an amnesiac, dubbed Rita, who's helpless and must stay under Betty's care. Adam Kesher is also in the dream, having what appears to be the single worst day of his life as he goes through misfortune after misfortune. Diane even attempts to rectify Camilla's assassination by portraying the hitman she hired as a bumbling, terrible killer - perhaps to convince herself that Camilla somehow got away safe.The masterful thing about this film isn't just how Lynch captures the tone and surreality of dreams, but how he makes everything seem so natural and unquestioned (just like while you're in the middle of a dream). When Betty moves into her aunt's apartment in LA, the landlord notes that another tenant used to have a "prize-fighting kangaroo" in his room. It's a one-off line, but no one questions a thing, and it's delivered in such a way that even the audience doesn't recognize the absurdity of the statement. Little things are off - people laugh for a moment more than they should, phrases are repeated like chants, and a triviality like espresso being bad can cause a catastrophe for the entire city. Every scene has you on the edge of your seat because you genuinely don't know what will happen next in this almost-normal, but slightly off world. It's a film that you can watch over and over again because the ride is just so entertaining.Mulholland Drive is the best David Lynch film, in my opinion. He creates a tragic mystery of projection and rejection, of love and hatred, with enough subtle clues to keep things grounded and provide excellent fodder for rewatch.

This movie is a brilliant puzzle if you want to solve it. If you don't like puzzles or dont't want to think about what you watch, just don't watch it. This movie requires you to think about it and makes sense out of it. If you don't want to spend time on that, go and watch American Pie or something. I don't think it necessarily means you are an idiot if you don't understand the movie but stop throwing mud to Lynch for not understanding it.

I'm sorry for the harsh rating, but people need to stop rating movies just because of their directors. Yes, David Lynch is a renowned, very experienced and versatile artist. Does that make up for the horrible dialogue, mediocre acting, very average cinematography and very inadequate length of this film? I don't think so...The Elephant Man was great and I understood the use of Surrealism in Eraserhead, but this is confusing for the sake of being confusing. No symbology, no threads to hold onto... a complete mess accompanied by a completely outdated soundtrack, which might as well have been written for Apocalypse Now. After reading some reviews, I am glad to say that there were no elements that were just too profound for me to grasp - everyone seems to be as lost (in what concerns to search for meaning) as I am. There is a natural tendency to assume something is genius when you simply don't get it, especially when it comes from such a great artist such as Lynch. I disagree! I simply did not enjoy this.
Mulholland Dr. (2001) 5/10Mulholland Dr. (2001) 5/10

Save yourself the agony. This movie never makes any sense and isn't summed up in the end. I can't believe it got any good reviews. Maybe people just like the actors - that's why I gave it a chance. Big Mistake. I wish someone would have given it a crummy review but it had so many stars and I like the players.Don't say I didn't warn you. This comes in second to the movie "Nothing But Trouble" which I still say is the most terrible movie I've had the misfortune to fall for.If you want a good story go for "3 Days To Kill" or "Tombstone". If you need something lighter just get something from Nora Ephron and you'll be fulfilled instead of bewildered by strangeness.(Maybe people put up with the strangeness because it's supposed to take place in California but it's just Waaaay Too Bizarre and leaves you with a feeling of "what the hell?" at the end)

I watched this movie again because I did not remember any part enough to register and make a memory. Therefore, a completely forgettable film.It is also very boring and manipulative like a guy you work with that won't go away. If this film was a person, you would report them to human resources and avoid their presence as much as possible. This was an incredible waste of time.

Review title: First two-thirds are intreguing. The rest is a mess.
Review_body: The first two-thirds of this movie is intriguing, where you are waiting for four seemingly unrelated threads to come together. It is interesting to see some of the mysteries come to light. The main thread is about Betty, who just moved to Hollywood in search of an acting career. She is staying in her aunt's apartment. But Rita is also staying in the apartment, a victim of amnesia. Rita has tens of thousands of dollars in cash and a strange key. That is the main mystery: What happened to Rita?The problem is that the answer (OK, there really is no answer) involves time warps, body switching, and alternate universes. And none of it makes any sense. It's utter garbage.The screenwriter had a great idea for a mystery, but had no idea how to conclude it. Perhaps he dropped LSD one night and whatever came into his mind he put in the movie. That's the most plausible explanation I can think of.

Review title: did i just have a bad trip?
Review_body: I don't know what i just watched but it sure as hell didn't deserve the 8/10 rating it has currently has on IMDb. In short there is no main story, almost everything is left to your own imagination.There are a ton of story lines but they don't give any answers and don't lead anywhere.It blows my mind that this movie is being rated as a masterpiece, in my opinion it was utter garbage.Did i already mention i did not enjoy this movie?1/10 and that's being generousx

Wow, I just watched the movie for the first time last night, and it was thee best movie I have ever seen, and probably the best I will ever see. The movie is a modern impressionists view on dreaming and the subconscious. I will probably end up watching this movie over and over until I find out what each piece of the puzzle symbolizes. Somebody tell me If I'm wrong: Man Behind Winkies: Manipulates peoples dreams Cowboy:Helps peoples nightmares turn into dreams Diane: Makes peoples dreams turn into nightmares Red Lamp: is always in a scene when the phone rings Old People:Her Emotions, at the beginning she is happy and the old people when she met the old people, but at the end her emotions(the old people) are attacking her. Blue triangular key: The beginning of a relationship Blue Box: the end of the relationship.Before the second credits begin at the beginning of the movie it reveals that Betty is falling asleep, it shows her in a dance contest, she wins and starts becoming famous, and everything revolves around her, until she goes to club Silencio, where she finds out that everything that she has been experiencing is an illusion. When she violently shakes she is starting to come out of her dream.

Review title: Somethings are good to be remain Unexpalined
Review_body:
THIS IS NOT REVIEW..but the way how everyone receives this Incredible Masterpiece
First of all watch the movie till the very ending.
For who already watched..You cannot help that this movie will surely get you to an arguement.why?
if you find why..that will be the real genre of the movie
Everyone dreams,,but is it so important than our reality?
Yesssssss....this is shown in the way that there is no particular point of view in this movie..if 100 persons watched this movie then 100 persons individualy understand the movie in 100 different ways...

I wouldn't say that I take films too seriously, I'll watch pretty much anything from 12 Angy Men to Grandma's Boy. With that in mind, Mulholland Dive is by far the wrist film I have ever seen.Poor acting, weak plot, terrible story telling and it looks cheap. Mulholland drive presents itself as a mystery but unravels as a series of bearly connected, seemingly random scene with many pontles characters and plot points (like the cowboy, the blue key, the singer, the box and the nightclub).Thinking about the way it the film ended fills me with anger and disappointment. Im not a good enough with words to express just how low an opinion I have of this film. If I could delete it from history, I would.

I've read a thousand comments about this film and I've yet to see one where someone "kinda" liked it. People are either disgusted with or in love with it. Rarely are movies made that are powerful enough to make people feel anything anymore. David Lynch should be proud. I believe that he was aiming for a confusing movie that people would be talking about for a long time, like it or not. I think he has succeeded brilliantly. I'm not posting this for argumentative purposes but am just explaining how I believe this film has done exactly what Lynch wanted it to do. What he wanted it to do was confuse people who enjoy being confused, make people think who enjoy thinking, and tick people off who don't like either of the previous two. I am completely capable of being wrong and could easily be wrong now but this is what I think on the subject. I love the film and enjoy just as much hearing about people hating it as I do them loving it. Great films should make people argue points.

This is the best film of all time. It's more than a movie, it's like a sip of cold water on a hot summer day. No other film caused me such a range of emotions! The most shocking, most intriguing, film, from which it is impossible to tear yourself away, is a film that with each new viewing becomes more interesting and interesting. I recommend all the fans of David Lynch and the author's cinema in general. PS: Sorry for my bad English) Rating 10/10 without options!

Review title: I'm waiting on my IOU to arrive
Review_body: ...because lynch owes me 2.5 hours of thrill seeking fun to help me get over what horrific waste of time this movie was. my brother gave up caring what was going on after 5 minutes. i had a real bad feeling halfway through that nothing would be solved by the end, and i should have acted on it. let me try to describe what watching this movie is like: you come into class one day to learn the alphabet. the teacher (lynch) writes up on the board klmnopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghij as slowly as is humanly possible, naming them as he goes along. only as he does this you realize that even though some of these letters look different he's calling a few by the same name. there are hints that it will all make sense very soon, a 'soon' that never comes. leaving class that day you talk to some of your friends who watched this lesson too to see what the hell is going on. they start in about all these letters being symbolic and yada yada. the next day you are forced to file a report with the local police that you've been raped after class by the teacher, because the feeling you're left with cannot be described as anything else.learn from my mistake, don't be a statistic

Mulholland Drive, Lynch's 2001 nightmare/mystery, is almost flawless in constitution. A most enthralling account and study on how Hollywood gobbles up and recycles its temporary thespian contributors. Using themes he first introduced in 'Lost Highway', Lynch manages to make concrete the almost ghost-like energy and remnants of the old Hollywood studio system. Blending a roster of old and new actors, he also masterfully weaves a miasma of interchangeable plot lines that almost too perfectly capture the climates now found in modern day LA. Originally meant to be a Television pilot for an ABC series, the foolish broadcasters chose to decline and passed on the series, already in development, in the last round. Lynch took it to French investors, added another 45 minutes of footage, and released it as his next film. Brilliant!!!

Review title: Mulholland Drive is a film with a key
Review_body: . That means you need to find the key to open it (its meanings), to read it. At the very beginning we see dancing couple multiplied over one another using so called "blue key", special effect used by TV to place a figure (shot in studio) inside an environment, usually exterior (street, nature etc.). If we take this as a key then we realize that two female characters (Rita and Betty) are actually one and the same woman (a box appears later in the film again with a blue key). Rita/Betty is dying after a car accident and in her last moments she sees her life  her coming to Hollywood as a young aspiring actress and her ending as a hooker. Death keeps appearing in different occasions and shapes. The Silenzio club is a place where Rita/Betty meet death on a stage. The singer is introduced by the announcer saying that the performance will be a"play-back". That means not being "live". That's why Rita/Betty cries. At the end of the movie there is also a very impressive appearance of deathetc. Mulholland Drive is a way to the other world, the world of death (in short).

MD can be interpreted in several different ways and is great in terms of acting, plot, atmosphere, and pace (although, like most other Lynch movies, the pace is leisurely). Many great moments and unforgettable characters. For a "thinking" movie, I think that it works because interpretations are possible given all information within the movie rather than having to draw upon outside literary references.It also works within Lynch's body of work. In many ways, he tells the same type of story in several of his movies. I would compare MD with Lost Highway, Blue Velvet, and Erasehead. As a more mature work, the story is told with more confidence, and with more daring (such as liberal use of time sequencing).

Mulholland Drive is an incredibly divisive movie; everyone seems to view it either as a masterpiece or an abomination, and this is understandable, as it is extremely confusing and subtle. Most confusing movies give enough clues and clear plot points to formulate a theory, although it still takes a lot of thought to piece together these clues. Mulholland Drive still gives these clues, but they're very subtle; it's hard to tell what's important, what isn't and how all these seemingly unconnected occurrences all connect. The narrative is far from conventional too, and this only adds to the mystery.This makes it quite clear why this movie is so divisive, because on first appearance, it can seem severely disjointed, incoherent and simply a mess, if you try to view it as a straightforward narrative. Nothing is made clear to the viewer, and so much is kept a mystery for so long, that it is completely understandable as to why it is such a frustrating and pointless movie to some, however I felt myself intrigued throughout. The constant mystery and subtle hints made me very interested and entertained for the whole movie; it always gave enough information to keep the viewer interested, but not a single bit more. The final 15-20 minutes gives many answers, but creates even more questions, the answers to which are all alluded to within the movie. Many criticise David Lynch of having no idea of what he was doing, and view this movie as only being liked because people think they are finding meaning in what is merely an incomprehensible mess, and I understand how people would think this given the subtlety of the clues and plot, and if you approach the movie thinking it's going to have a straightforward narrative then you will come out disappointed and confused. However, the clues are there, and David Lynch has crafted this movie so carefully and precisely that if you put a lot of thought into it afterwards, you will be able to put together your own theory and ideas.As for the other aspects of the movie, the cinematography is spectacular, particularly in one standout scene early in the movie, in which the camera is used effectively to create maximum tension. I was apprehensive about the acting at first, mainly due to Naomi Watts' character, as it felt a little forced and unnatural, but soon I realised that it was just the character's personality and she displayed some great acting throughout the movie. The musical score was great too, and overall everything was incredibly well done, I didn't feel that anything dragged down the quality,But of course, the standout feature was the plot, which was masterfully crafted with intense precision to elicit intrigue, and remain in the minds of the viewers for a long time afterwards. It truly is a masterful, if often misunderstood movie, which I believe fully deserves its praise.
Mulholland Dr is the best movie that I've ever seen.

Review title: Creativity does not have to make sense...
Review_body: This film is unique! It is creative! It is the most overrated piece of crap I've ever watched! This movie is cruel; only in the sense that it draws you in by being very interesting only to disappoint in the end. Like a great film, Mulholland Dr. feels like it is gradually building up to some grand finale where everything becomes crystal clear and you wonder why you didn't figure it out sooner. Unfortunately, the end result is no grand finale! In fact, within a matter of minutes you suddenly feel as though you're watching a completely different film that just happens to have the same characters. It is as if the writer/director had two completely different ideas for this film, couldn't pick one and just decided to combine the two. As the film climaxed/became unwatchable, I couldn't help but think that I somehow missed something along the way and maybe this was just my fault. Luckily, as I watched it for a second time(a couple MORE hours I'll never get back) I realized that it was not me that missed some key detail or moment in the film. It was the film itself that was flawed. Seriously, I have no idea why this movie was even made. Maybe the studio just wanted to watch Naomi Watts get naughty with another woman. If you're looking for entertainment you would be better off watching another movie. All that you will find here is frustration!

Review title: Lesbian sex, a blue box, and murderous old people.
Review_body: Forgive me if I put a damper on all of your enthusiasm, but I find this movie extremely disturbing. "The worst movie ever made" would be a generous title, at best. It's as though Lynch filmed three different movies, accidentally set fire to each of the reels, spliced the remnants of the inferno together, found a producer, and stuck the piece of crap on a DVD for all to hate. I would rather rub raw meat on my eyes have rats chew off my eyelids and hot wax poured into my eyeballs than ever watch this filth again. The first thing i thought of when the movie was finished was that i wasted 2.5 hours of my life that i will never ever be able to redeem. David Lynch missed the memo on what constitutes a good film. Last time i checked music, dialogue, and - god forbid - plot were relatively crucial ingredients to a story worth more than a slit wrist.

David Lynch is difficult because he makes demands on his audience. He takes meticulous care to fabricate an atmosphere that is, culturally speaking, a collation. The clothes, music, and behavioral idiom is out of pace, yet we see ourselves. Stranger than anything we could have imagined, his world is finally recognizable as our own. If genius is the ability to make connections, David Lynch is a genius of film who connects inner experience to the objects and individuals from without that mold and influence it. MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a film preoccupied with identity. On its surface, it is the story of a young woman who won a dance contest and a chance to have a Hollywood audition. Though by no means clear until much later in the film, she has mediocre talent and falls prey to destructive seductions that turn her dream into a nightmare and destroy her. But what Lynch has done with this Hollywood cliché is magical. It's all in the telling: his trick is to hide his story by cryptically putting it right in front of you. Time after time, the viewer's conventional expectations lead to wrong conclusions, raising the level of confusion and suspense. Like BLUE VELVET, MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a mystery, told from an emotional rather than a rational language of meaning. This is important to realize; it's why Lynch is unintelligible to so many. Without Freudian understanding, the depth of his insight and the richness of his art cannot be comprehended consciously. The meticulous clues that he puts before yousometimes literally in your facewill be misread or overlooked. BLUE VELVET, an Oedipal allegory, takes a tour through the mindscapes of sex and guilt in a young man processing the shock of his father's heart attack. MULHOLLAND DRIVE similarly works from the inside out, but its canvass is much larger, challenging the validity of American optimism. By using the metaphor of dreams, he explores the conflict between the ideal of Hollywood as a dream machine, and the corrosive realities of life. Dreams can be beautiful and turn terrifying. Dreams always express a wish, often reversing facts of the waking world. More importantly, as Freud insisted, the dream is the dreamer. Hollywood creates the dreams of our culture, projecting the sex and violence of our collective Id. Id is very much the springboard for David Lynch. For most of the entire film, MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a dream being dreamt by a young aspiring actress named Betty. This is not explicit, though in typical fashion Lynch has put it subtly in front of us: in the opening scene the camera plays on a pillow and we hear the sound of a person sleeping out of range. In a subsequent scene Betty says, "This is the place of dreams." Then the camera follows a limousine traveling at night on Mulholland Drive. It soon becomes a hearse of sorts, and that subliminal impression, once planted, remains. Throughout the film/Betty's dream, the characters and their actions must often be inverted to understand their interplay as continuous to the fabric of the story. By this calculus it is Betty, not Rita, who is searching for her identity, and the story of Betty's triumphant audition is her wish that she had not, in reality, failed. When Adam, the director, meets her eyes and seems to fall in love with her, we should suspect the truth is his indifference. When Rita begins to sense that she is responsible for a murder, Freud's delineation of dreamwork points to Betty. In dreams, manifest content masks latent meaning; there are layers and layers. Dreams are constructed from images of waking life: we later discover the sources of Betty's dream material: the dark angular man in the diner, the waitress's name tag, a blue key, are reproduced in Betty's dream with a significance they did not have when she casually encountered them. But we don't know that to begin with. We do know that walls, doors, windows, boxes, and bed are the symbols of Betty's entrapment, culminating in a vision of Silencio, the place of truth and "crying" where Death is the keeper of dreams. Cartoon gangsters shorn of their menace through slapstick, should be viewed with foreboding, for everything is its opposite. Here too, the Cowboy's mythic strength is denatured, stripped of his status as icon; he is not a benign protector, rather he seems more a genderless demon who awakens Betty/Diane to what we shortly learn is Diane's horrible reality. The lesbian affair between Betty and Rita is in fact a destructive union riven with ungovernable passions. In one of the last scenes Diane masturbates furiously, missing her orgasm repeatedly as a final frustration before the barrier to guilt gives way and parental homunculi creep under the doorway, exploding into the room as an Id-fueled horror of accusation. Proust wrote that there is no access to something original because, by virtue of its originality, it defies analysis, it can only stand apart with a life of its own as a reference to subsequent works that may evolve under its influence. "In short, this art which is so complicated is in fact the only living art. It alone expresses for others and renders visible to ourselves that life of ours that cannot effectually observe itself and of which the observable manifestations need to be translated and, often, to be read backwards and laboriously deciphered." David Lynch is such an artist, and MULHOLLAND DRIVE is such a film. Any attempt to force his meaning will fail; he will not be understood too quickly, and perhaps never in the same way by different viewers. To paraphrase T.S. Eliot on Shakespeare, all we can hope for in time is to be wrong about him in a new way.

Review title: There is no band, It's all on tape, it's just a movie in which we can participate and escape. It's a movie as an expressive substation between the real world and the dream.
Review_body: I highly agree with this comment and it helped me interpreting the movie much more better. But I really liked to expend the comment by sharing my ideas in a more constructive base. Since I have been watching the films of David lynch, I've become interested in the construction of narratives. Like in Lost Highway (which has been criticized to be to disturbed and chaotic) the director wants to make a film where we can forget the Conservative Hollywood-story lines. To really enjoy a film as an aesthetic expressing we need to watch these movies with a more abstract perspective (why do a lot of Picasso's paintings become so famous?; most books write about the participative in the discussions of "what is the real?" and "How does art react on it?")As David lynch has been arguing: we need to see his film in a way we can watch a Picasso painting, were perspectives and context change. Also his films are constructed with a collection of paintings (24 or more per second) and in between there are abstract connections. When we let part of the importance of narrative go, and watch his movies more on a artistic way, we could understand his participation in the film art-discussion. There is no band, It's all on tape, it's just a movie, a dream in which we can participate and escape. It's a movie as an expressive substation between the real world and the dream. It is the link between the concrete things and objects with their arbitrary meanings, and the possibility of complete abstract feelings and psychological ideas.When we dream, we mix all the persons we know. These person do other thing. We see them from other perspectives and other contexts.Where a lot of criticism on Vertov's film "the man with the movie camera" is based on the discussion of the myth of photographic reality, and the function of film. We like to ignore the idea that this film could also be an expression on the October revolution during the upcoming communism, where women been asked to "stand up" and participate in the social- and working practices. It the reversed way of looking at Lynch's movies and hold on to the demand for comprehensible normal structured narrative and ignore the contribution to the discussion on film art in the wide world artistic forum of movie makers and criticism.

Can someone please explain this movie to me, I've watched it three times and I still don't understand it. Can someone please tell me who is who, and what everything means, because I am so lost, I've tried to figure it out and I can't. I understand Betty and Rita up until the music/concert thingo they went to, then all the characters make no sense to me, them included, why is everyones names changed around. What was with the dead lady on the bed, and the man in the coffee shop who had the dream and then saw that person/thing outside. And what do those small old man and lady have to do with anything. I am so confused about the whole movie, please someone explain it to me, lol.

After viewing this film, i was not only completely and utterly confused by it but also was left with a bitter taste. Other reviews say that this movie is "perfect," and "Lynch at his best." However I felt that for the majority of the film, all the dialogue seemed forced, unrealistic and about as smooth as a piece of sandpaper. This was the first film by Lynch that I had ever seen, and I am now turned off after hearing his writing style. The visuals are, I will admit, very dramatic and effective to the scene. The only problem was that I had no idea what was happening in the scene. By far the best part of the movie was the lesbian sex scene. What else is there to say.

There's not much good that can be said about "Mulholland Drive." To be fair, it actually starts out with some interesting aspects, but nothing ever plays out to anything in the end making the movie a concoction of several random events, several of which don't even fit in with any explanation fans of this movie will try to provide.The movie doesn't even present a valid event on the part of director David Lynch. Lynch has used the same plot twist/technique in this movie that he's used at least two or three times in the past. "Lost Highway" is a prime example of a past Lynch movie that has used this technique. This is what seems to pass for creativity today: recycling past ideas and calling it something new. I wouldn't complain AS much if the movie actually made any coherent sense in the end. But one of the major problems of this movie is that it doesn't. Fans will try to claim that the movie does make sense, but it is not understandable without the help of online explanations. Even with these explanations, the explanation still isn't clear and discernible from the movie itself.This movie would not receive nearly the following that it does if it were not made by David Lynch. Because Lynch has gotten away with this type of thing in the past, he's allowed to get away with it again. Lynch appears to be above the law as far as movie making goes. If any other director had attempted to make this movie, they wouldn't get away with it. If it were any director's debut movie, the director would likely be shunned and never direct again.This movie is officially on the number one spot of the worst movies I have ever seen. Take my advice. Don't waste your two and a half hours.

The film is the very pinnacle of cinema in a critical sense. The problem is the way the film is presented to the audience. The film starts with a dream. And throughout the dream, the viewer expects the culmination, clarification, unfolding of the story. However, that is not happening. The dream (shown without clarification) suddenly ends. With the ending of the dream, the audience is shown the real life of the main character, which is much worse than the dream (which also shows the main character's need for daydreaming-dreaming). All of that is probably great on the part of a film critic, but on the part of an ordinary viewer (who spent 2 hours waiting for the story-dream to unfold, only to eventually stop the story and take a completely different direction) certainly isn't.

Can this be any better than already is? NO. i know there will be people saying yes maybe, but it's already done for and its hands down amazingly beautiful in every way. Questions from start to end....it cracks my brain open and loving it. This being the second film watching from Lynch has made me a fan right when the credits showed. I now'E seen other's and they're all gratefully made. But i just cant seem to purely Love the other films like this one. Don't want to ruin scenes and tell much at all. Top of all movies in my favorite list to be at the number 1 spot. Don't know why but I now consider calling Naomi Watts Mulholland Dr.

I want to give shortest review to this movie. Intriguing very strange but masterpiece from David Lynch. I enjoyed this movie and didnt move a muscle while watching this is sick movie. Brilliant performance by Naomi Watts such a talented actress. Lynch is next level director!

Wonderful acting, awesome lighting and stage design, shining directory from David Lynch and an interesting subject all and all could be a reason to unveil an outstanding thriller movie! but not with a boring and so much confusing storytelling. you will lose your interest after 30 minutes and after 2 hour you will finally start to find out where is this going to! yes I know what happens and when but first let's answer to a question: What's your point from watching a movie? enjoying it or getting bored and confused so you have to struggle with it? Lynch Twisted his massages with ambiguity and mystery, being mysterious is Interesting and fascinating but you'll overdose if you consume it too much. So it's my opinion: Mulholland DR. was first movie which made me think it didn't worth my time.
I couldn't convince myself to rate more than 5/10.

Review title: L.A. at Night - A submersion into dark desperation and hopeless solitude
Review_body: Mulholland Drive is one of the top films created in the last 10 years, and it makes my top-10 list of all-time.Now, this is not what I would call a great movie - but rather, this is a fantastic film - and give me a great film over a great movie any day of the week. Great movies make you feel something while you are inside the theater, but great films go home with you and consume your soul for months and years to come. Great films are also: well written, offer thorough character development, well-acted, smartly shot, and treat their audiences in an intelligent manner. There is nothing worse than seeing a movie and / or film which insults the audience's intelligence.Now, let's make this simple -(Mulholland Drive "simple"? yeah right....)Here's what I love about the film: Naomi Watts is both effortless and flawless in her delivery - what an actress.....; Robert Forster's role (Detective McKnight)- albeit limited, was so very well-timed and properly placed within the film; Lynch's spicy color schemes are as simultaneously vibrant, disturbing, stunning, bizarre, uneasy and awkward which is a direct reflection of his characters. And the soundtrack? - oh me oh my..... the soundtrack.....it's as chilling and dark as my hallway at 3:00 am.Laura Harring is a rare and precious gem constantly reminding us of the great Rita Hayworth and her all-encompassing and extraordinary embodiment of beauty; Justin Theroux accomplishes so much in his role that I wouldn't know where to begin; and just the idea of casting Ann Miller (Louise Bonner) for her role as "Coco" brings those words "Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer" back to life for the audience - as well as a longing for a resurgence of the great movie musical.I fall in love with L.A. (especially L.A. at night) all over again every time I view this film. When I think of L.A. I think of all the people and things I have lost in my life. But I also think about what could possibly happen 5 minutes from now and how my life could change entirely. Then I begin to look around and think of all that garbage and evil such as despair, loneliness, cruelty, greed, lust, crime and poverty. But, maybe this sick cycle simply feeds my love for L.A. There is a haunting beauty that is associated with all of these elements; perhaps it is the idea that although we are constantly reminded of the evil in the world, there is always hope - hope that, one day, things will right themselves, and for each of us - our dreams of the perfect life and the perfect world will be realized.David Lynch has always been a favorite of mine as far as Directors go, and Mulholland Drive is just another disturbing, but ravishing piece of work generated from the mind of this genius. Mulholland Drive is an extremely abstract film that is wide-open for individual interpretation - and, for myself and for fans of this film, that truly is the fun part. If you choose to show this film to friends or family, choose your audience wisely. Invite your film lovers to your next showing, but lock the door if the "movie-lovers" want to join-in. Still, no matter who your audience is, expect some frustration, tons of questions, and confusion beyond belief. But, most of all, while Mulholland Drive is showing, expect a great deal of silence (silencio).Thanks for reading - and enjoy!

Self important drivel. When I watched it I thought it was like Twin Peaks. Didnt know it was David Lynch. So dated. Was an interesting story but soon petered out with very confused forced 'surrealist' last half hour or so. Dont bother.
I loved it so much. It's not only a thriller movie but also an invitation to the realm of psychology. It aroused my interest in learning more about psychology.

Among the worst movie ever seen: the plot is frequently interrupted and changes direction, peculiar situations aren't clarified. And this is not the result of a project, but just the result of approximation and improvvisation. Things belonging to a scene are no more there (and no one care of this), the blue key changes its shape from one scene to the next one (and no one care of this), camera operators are seen reflected in mirrors and other facts like these. The Director can't hid himself behind his fame justifying every mistake with this fact: the film is superficial and improvised and the public certified this fact by not attending the cinemas stating the movie as a real flop.
For The Director (FTD) should be this movies rating. It is a self indulgent movie and should have an audience warning!

The Silencio scene is a microcosm for the more general force of the movie, its dream-like quality, dream in the double sense, the one sense being as opposed to wakefulness and the other sense being as a deep wish, fantasy, or longing------------that beautiful song being artificial, and then just the virtuosic job of presenting the dream-like quality, the fact that certain actors were cast to look like Naomi Watts, and how iconic some of the characters and places are, as far as characters go I will refer you especially to Mimi I think her name is, the women that manages the apartment complex Naomi is living in. And then the end, that last shot with the faces of the two women staggered and the music and Naomi smiling, glowing, that incandescent smile.
